Result |  [Allied](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II") victory

  * Collapse of [Nazi Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany")
  * Fall of [Japanese](/wiki/Empire_of_Japan "Empire of Japan") and [Italian Empires](/wiki/Italian_Empire "Italian Empire")
  * Dissolution of the [League of Nations](/wiki/League_of_Nations "League of Nations")
  * Creation of the [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations")
  * Emergence of the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States") and the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") as [superpowers](/wiki/Superpower "Superpower")
  * Beginning of the [Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War") ([more...](/wiki/World_War_II#Aftermath "World War II"))

**World War II** (often abbreviated to **WWII** or **WW2**), also known as the
**Second World War** , was a [global war](/wiki/World_war "World war") that
lasted from 1939 to 1945, although related conflicts began earlier. It
involved [the vast majority of the world's
countries](/wiki/World_War_II_by_country "World War II by country")—including
all of the [great powers](/wiki/Great_power "Great power")—eventually forming
two opposing [military alliances](/wiki/Military_alliance "Military
alliance"): the [Allies](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War
II") and the [Axis](/wiki/Axis_powers "Axis powers"). It was the most
widespread war in history, and directly involved more than 100 million people
from over 30 countries. In a state of [total war](/wiki/Total_war "Total
war"), the major participants threw their entire economic, industrial, and
scientific capabilities behind the [war effort](/wiki/War_effort "War
effort"), erasing the distinction between civilian and military resources.

World War II was the [deadliest
conflict](/wiki/List_of_wars_and_anthropogenic_disasters_by_death_toll "List
of wars and anthropogenic disasters by death toll") in [human
history](/wiki/History_of_the_world "History of the world"), marked by 50
million to 85 million fatalities, most of which were civilians in the Soviet
Union and China. It included [massacres](/wiki/Massacres "Massacres"), the
deliberate genocide of [the Holocaust](/wiki/The_Holocaust "The Holocaust"),
[strategic bombing](/wiki/Strategic_bombing_during_World_War_II "Strategic
bombing during World War II"), starvation, disease and the first use of
[nuclear weapons](/wiki/Nuclear_weapon "Nuclear weapon") in
history.[1][2][3][4]

The [Empire of Japan](/wiki/Empire_of_Japan "Empire of Japan") aimed to
dominate [Asia](/wiki/Asia "Asia") and the [Pacific](/wiki/Pacific_Ocean
"Pacific Ocean") and was already [at war](/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War
"Second Sino-Japanese War") with the [Republic of
China](/wiki/Republic_of_China_\(1912%E2%80%9349\) "Republic of China
\(1912–49\)") in 1937,[5] but the world war is generally said to have begun on
1 September 1939[6] with the [invasion](/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland "Invasion of
Poland") of [Poland](/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic "Second Polish Republic") by
[Nazi Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany") and subsequent declarations
of war on Germany by [France](/wiki/French_Third_Republic "French Third
Republic") and the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom").
[Supplied by the Soviet
Union](/wiki/German%E2%80%93Soviet_Commercial_Agreement_\(1940\)
"German–Soviet Commercial Agreement \(1940\)"), from late 1939 to early 1941,
in a series of campaigns and [treaties](/wiki/Tripartite_Pact "Tripartite
Pact"), Germany conquered or controlled much of continental Europe, and formed
the Axis alliance with [Italy](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy "Kingdom of Italy") and
[Japan](/wiki/Empire_of_Japan "Empire of Japan"). Under the
[Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact](/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact
"Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact") of August 1939, Germany and the [Soviet
Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") partitioned and annexed territories
of their European neighbours, [Poland](/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Poland "Soviet
invasion of Poland"), [Finland](/wiki/Winter_War "Winter War"),
[Romania](/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_Bessarabia_and_Northern_Bukovina "Soviet
occupation of Bessarabia and Northern Bukovina") and the [Baltic
states](/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Baltic_states "Occupation of the Baltic
states"). The war continued primarily between the European Axis powers and the
coalition of the United Kingdom and the [British
Commonwealth](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations "Commonwealth of Nations"), with
campaigns including the [North Africa](/wiki/Western_Desert_Campaign "Western
Desert Campaign") and [East
Africa](/wiki/East_African_Campaign_\(World_War_II\) "East African Campaign
\(World War II\)") campaigns, the aerial [Battle of
Britain](/wiki/Battle_of_Britain "Battle of Britain"), the [Blitz bombing
campaign](/wiki/The_Blitz "The Blitz"), the [Balkan
Campaign](/wiki/Balkan_Campaign_\(World_War_II\) "Balkan Campaign \(World War
II\)") as well as the long-running [Battle of the
Atlantic](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Atlantic "Battle of the Atlantic"). On 22 June
1941, the European Axis powers launched [an invasion of the Soviet
Union](/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa "Operation Barbarossa"), opening the
[largest land theatre of war in history](/wiki/Eastern_Front_\(World_War_II\)
"Eastern Front \(World War II\)"), which trapped the major part of the Axis
military forces into a [war of attrition](/wiki/Attrition_warfare "Attrition
warfare"). In December 1941, Japan [attacked the United
States](/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor "Attack on Pearl Harbor") and [European
colonies](/wiki/Japanese_invasion_of_Malaya "Japanese invasion of Malaya") in
the Pacific Ocean, and quickly conquered much of the Western Pacific.

The Axis advance halted in 1942 when Japan lost the critical [Battle of
Midway](/wiki/Battle_of_Midway "Battle of Midway"), and Germany and Italy were
defeated in [North Africa](/wiki/Second_Battle_of_El_Alamein "Second Battle of
El Alamein") and then, decisively, at [Stalingrad](/wiki/Battle_of_Stalingrad
"Battle of Stalingrad") in the Soviet Union. In 1943, with a series of German
defeats on the [Eastern Front](/wiki/Eastern_Front_\(World_War_II\) "Eastern
Front \(World War II\)"), the [Allied invasion of
Sicily](/wiki/Allied_invasion_of_Sicily "Allied invasion of Sicily") and the
[Allied invasion of Italy](/wiki/Allied_invasion_of_Italy "Allied invasion of
Italy") which brought about Italian surrender, and Allied victories in the
Pacific, the Axis lost the initiative and undertook strategic retreat on all
fronts. In 1944, the Western Allies [invaded German-occupied
France](/wiki/Normandy_landings "Normandy landings"), while the Soviet Union
regained all of its territorial losses and invaded Germany and its allies.
During 1944 and 1945 the Japanese suffered major reverses in mainland Asia in
[South](/wiki/Second_Guangxi_Campaign "Second Guangxi Campaign") [Central
China](/wiki/Battle_of_West_Hunan "Battle of West Hunan") and
[Burma](/wiki/Burma_Campaign "Burma Campaign"), while the Allies crippled the
[Japanese Navy](/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Navy "Imperial Japanese Navy") and
captured key Western Pacific islands.

The war in [Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe") concluded with an [invasion of
Germany](/wiki/Western_Allied_invasion_of_Germany "Western Allied invasion of
Germany") by the Western Allies and the Soviet Union, culminating in the
[capture of Berlin](/wiki/Battle_of_Berlin "Battle of Berlin") by Soviet
troops, the [suicide of Adolf Hitler](/wiki/Death_of_Adolf_Hitler "Death of
Adolf Hitler") and the subsequent [German unconditional
surrender](/wiki/German_Instrument_of_Surrender "German Instrument of
Surrender") on [8 May 1945](/wiki/Victory_in_Europe_Day "Victory in Europe
Day"). Following the [Potsdam Declaration](/wiki/Potsdam_Declaration "Potsdam
Declaration") by the Allies on 26 July 1945 and the refusal of Japan to
surrender under its terms, the United States [dropped atomic
bombs](/wiki/Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki "Atomic bombings of
Hiroshima and Nagasaki") on the Japanese cities of [Hiroshima](/wiki/Hiroshima
"Hiroshima") and [Nagasaki](/wiki/Nagasaki "Nagasaki") on 6 August and 9
August respectively. With an [invasion of the Japanese
archipelago](/wiki/Operation_Downfall "Operation Downfall") imminent, the
possibility of additional atomic bombings and the [Soviet invasion of
Manchuria](/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria "Soviet invasion of Manchuria"),
[Japan formally surrendered](/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan "Surrender of Japan") on
2 September 1945. Thus ended the war in Asia, cementing the total victory of
the Allies.

World War II altered the political alignment and social structure of the
world. The [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations") (UN) was
established to foster international co-operation and prevent future conflicts.
The victorious [great powers](/wiki/Great_power "Great power")—China, France,
the Soviet Union, the United Kingdom, and the United States—became the
[permanent
members](/wiki/Permanent_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council
"Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council") of the [United
Nations Security Council](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council "United
Nations Security Council").[7] The Soviet Union and the United States emerged
as rival [superpowers](/wiki/Superpower "Superpower"), setting the stage for
the [Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War"), which lasted for the next 46 years.
Meanwhile, the influence of European great powers waned, while the
[decolonisation of Africa](/wiki/Decolonisation_of_Africa "Decolonisation of
Africa") and [Asia](/wiki/Decolonisation_of_Asia "Decolonisation of Asia")
began. Most countries whose industries had been damaged moved towards
[economic recovery](/wiki/Post%E2%80%93World_War_II_economic_expansion
"Post–World War II economic expansion"). Political integration, especially [in
Europe](/wiki/European_integration "European integration"), emerged as an
effort to end pre-war enmities and to create a common identity.[8]

The start of the war in Europe is generally held to be 1 September
1939,[9][10] beginning with the [German invasion of
Poland](/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland "Invasion of Poland"); Britain and France
declared war on Germany two days later. The dates for the beginning of war in
the Pacific include the start of the [Second Sino-Japanese
War](/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War "Second Sino-Japanese War") on 7 July
1937,[11][12] or even the [Japanese invasion of
Manchuria](/wiki/Japanese_invasion_of_Manchuria "Japanese invasion of
Manchuria") on 19 September 1931.[13][14]

Others follow the British historian [A. J. P. Taylor](/wiki/A._J._P._Taylor
"A. J. P. Taylor"), who held that the Sino-Japanese War and war in Europe and
its colonies occurred simultaneously and the two wars merged in 1941. This
article uses the conventional dating. Other starting dates sometimes used for
World War II include the [Italian invasion of Abyssinia](/wiki/Second_Italo-
Ethiopian_War "Second Italo-Ethiopian War") on 3 October 1935.[15] The British
historian [Antony Beevor](/wiki/Antony_Beevor "Antony Beevor") views the
beginning of World War II as the [Battles of Khalkhin
Gol](/wiki/Battles_of_Khalkhin_Gol "Battles of Khalkhin Gol") fought between
Japan and the forces of [Mongolia](/wiki/Mongolia "Mongolia") and the Soviet
Union from May to September 1939.[16]

The exact date of the war's end is also not universally agreed upon. It was
generally accepted at the time that the war ended with the
[armistice](/wiki/Armistice "Armistice") of 14 August 1945 ([V-J
Day](/wiki/Victory_over_Japan_Day "Victory over Japan Day")), rather than the
formal surrender of Japan (2 September 1945). A [peace treaty with
Japan](/wiki/Treaty_of_San_Francisco "Treaty of San Francisco") was signed in
1951.[17] A [treaty regarding Germany's
future](/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Final_Settlement_with_Respect_to_Germany "Treaty
on the Final Settlement with Respect to Germany") allowed the [reunification
of East and West Germany](/wiki/German_reunification "German reunification")
to take place in 1990 and resolved other post-World War II issues.[18]

## Background

Main article: [Causes of World War II](/wiki/Causes_of_World_War_II "Causes of
World War II")

### Europe

[World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I") had radically altered the
[political](/wiki/Geopolitics "Geopolitics") European map, with the defeat of
the [Central Powers](/wiki/Central_Powers "Central Powers")—including
[Austria-Hungary](/wiki/Austria-Hungary "Austria-Hungary"),
[Germany](/wiki/German_Empire "German Empire"),
[Bulgaria](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Bulgaria "Kingdom of Bulgaria") and the [Ottoman
Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire")—and the 1917
[Bolshevik](/wiki/Bolshevik "Bolshevik") [seizure of
power](/wiki/October_Revolution "October Revolution") in
[Russia](/wiki/Russian_Republic "Russian Republic"), which eventually led to
the founding of the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union").
Meanwhile, the victorious [Allies of World War I](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I
"Allies of World War I"), such as France, Belgium, Italy, Romania and Greece
gained territory, and new [nation-states](/wiki/Nation-states "Nation-states")
were created out of the collapse of Austria-Hungary and the Ottoman and
[Russian Empires](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Bundesarchiv_Bild_102-09042%2C_Genf%2C_V%C3%B6lkerbund%2C_Sitzungssaal.jpg/220px-
Bundesarchiv_Bild_102-09042%2C_Genf%2C_V%C3%B6lkerbund%2C_Sitzungssaal.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_102-09042,_Genf,_V%C3%B6lkerbund,_Sitzungssaal.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_102-09042,_Genf,_V%C3%B6lkerbund,_Sitzungssaal.jpg
"Enlarge")

The [League of Nations](/wiki/League_of_Nations "League of Nations") assembly,
held in [Geneva](/wiki/Geneva "Geneva"), [Switzerland](/wiki/Switzerland
"Switzerland"), 1930

To prevent a future world war, the [League of Nations](/wiki/League_of_Nations
"League of Nations") was created during the [1919 Paris Peace
Conference](/wiki/Paris_Peace_Conference,_1919 "Paris Peace Conference,
1919"). The organisation's primary goals were to prevent armed conflict
through [collective security](/wiki/Collective_security "Collective
security"), military and [naval disarmament](/wiki/Washington_Naval_Treaty
"Washington Naval Treaty"), and settling international disputes through
peaceful negotiations and arbitration.

Despite strong [pacifist](/wiki/Pacifism "Pacifism") sentiment [after World
War I](/wiki/Aftermath_of_World_War_I "Aftermath of World War I"),[19] its
aftermath still caused [irredentist](/wiki/Irredentist "Irredentist") and
[revanchist](/wiki/Revanchist "Revanchist") [nationalism](/wiki/Nationalism
"Nationalism") in several European states. These sentiments were especially
marked in Germany because of the significant territorial, colonial, and
financial losses incurred by the [Treaty of
Versailles](/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles "Treaty of Versailles"). Under the
treaty, Germany lost around 13 per cent of its home territory and all of [its
overseas possessions](/wiki/German_colonial_empire "German colonial empire"),
while German annexation of other states was prohibited,
[reparations](/wiki/World_War_I_reparations "World War I reparations") were
imposed, and limits were placed on the size and capability of the country's
[armed forces](/wiki/Reichswehr "Reichswehr").[20]

The German Empire was dissolved in the [German Revolution of
1918–1919](/wiki/German_Revolution_of_1918%E2%80%931919 "German Revolution of
1918–1919"), and a democratic government, later known as the [Weimar
Republic](/wiki/Weimar_Republic "Weimar Republic"), was created. The interwar
period saw strife between supporters of the new republic and hardline
opponents on both the [right](/wiki/Right-wing_politics "Right-wing politics")
and [left](/wiki/Left-wing_politics "Left-wing politics"). Italy, as an
Entente ally, had made some post-war territorial gains; however, Italian
nationalists were angered that the [promises
made](/wiki/Treaty_of_London_\(1915\) "Treaty of London \(1915\)") by Britain
and France to secure Italian entrance into the war were not fulfilled in the
peace settlement. From 1922 to 1925, the [Fascist](/wiki/Italian_Fascism
"Italian Fascism") movement led by [Benito Mussolini](/wiki/Benito_Mussolini
"Benito Mussolini") seized power in Italy with a nationalist,
[totalitarian](/wiki/Totalitarianism "Totalitarianism"), and [class
collaborationist](/wiki/Class_collaboration "Class collaboration") agenda that
abolished representative democracy, repressed socialist, left-wing and liberal
forces, and pursued an aggressive expansionist foreign policy aimed at making
Italy a [world power](/wiki/World_power "World power"), promising the creation
of a "[New Roman Empire](/wiki/New_Roman_Empire "New Roman Empire")".[21]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Bundesarchiv_Bild_102-10541%2C_Weimar%2C_Aufmarsch_der_Nationalsozialisten.jpg/220px-
Bundesarchiv_Bild_102-10541%2C_Weimar%2C_Aufmarsch_der_Nationalsozialisten.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_102-10541,_Weimar,_Aufmarsch_der_Nationalsozialisten.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_102-10541,_Weimar,_Aufmarsch_der_Nationalsozialisten.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Adolf Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler") at a German [National
Socialist](/wiki/National_Socialist "National Socialist") political rally in
[Weimar](/wiki/Weimar "Weimar"), October 1930

Adolf Hitler, after an [unsuccessful attempt to overthrow the German
government](/wiki/Beer_Hall_Putsch "Beer Hall Putsch") in 1923, eventually
became the [Chancellor of Germany in
1933](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler%27s_rise_to_power "Adolf Hitler's rise to power"). He
abolished democracy, espousing a [radical, racially motivated revision of the
world order](/wiki/New_Order_\(Nazism\) "New Order \(Nazism\)"), and soon
began a massive [rearmament campaign](/wiki/German_re-armament "German re-
armament").[22] Meanwhile, France, to secure its alliance, [allowed Italy a
free hand in Ethiopia](/wiki/Franco-Italian_Agreement "Franco-Italian
Agreement"), which Italy desired as a colonial possession. The situation was
aggravated in early 1935 when the [Territory of the Saar
Basin](/wiki/Saar_\(League_of_Nations\) "Saar \(League of Nations\)") was
legally reunited with Germany and Hitler repudiated the Treaty of Versailles,
accelerated his rearmament programme, and introduced
[conscription](/wiki/Conscription "Conscription").[23]

To contain Germany, the United Kingdom, France and Italy formed the [Stresa
Front](/wiki/Stresa_Front "Stresa Front") in April 1935; however, that June,
the United Kingdom made an [independent naval agreement](/wiki/Anglo-
German_Naval_Agreement "Anglo-German Naval Agreement") with Germany, easing
prior restrictions. The Soviet Union, concerned by [Germany's goals of
capturing vast areas of Eastern Europe](/wiki/Drang_nach_Osten "Drang nach
Osten"), drafted a treaty of mutual assistance with France. Before taking
effect though, the [Franco-Soviet pact](/wiki/Franco-Soviet_pact "Franco-
Soviet pact") was required to go through the bureaucracy of the League of
Nations, which rendered it essentially toothless.[24] The United States,
concerned with events in Europe and Asia, passed the [Neutrality
Act](/wiki/Neutrality_Acts_of_1930s "Neutrality Acts of 1930s") in August of
the same year.[25]

Hitler defied the Versailles and [Locarno treaties](/wiki/Locarno_treaties
"Locarno treaties") by
[remilitarising](/wiki/Remilitarization_of_the_Rhineland "Remilitarization of
the Rhineland") the [Rhineland](/wiki/Rhineland "Rhineland") in March 1936,
encountering little opposition.[26] In October 1936, Germany and Italy formed
the [Rome–Berlin Axis](/wiki/Rome%E2%80%93Berlin_Axis "Rome–Berlin Axis"). A
month later, Germany and Japan signed the [Anti-Comintern Pact](/wiki/Anti-
Comintern_Pact "Anti-Comintern Pact"), which Italy would join in the following
year.

### Asia

The [Kuomintang](/wiki/Kuomintang "Kuomintang") (KMT) party in China launched
a [unification campaign](/wiki/Northern_Expedition "Northern Expedition")
against [regional warlords](/wiki/Warlord_Era "Warlord Era") and nominally
unified China in the mid-1920s, but was soon embroiled in a [civil
war](/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War "Chinese Civil War") against its former [Chinese
Communist Party](/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party "Chinese Communist Party")
allies[27] and [new regional warlords](/wiki/Central_Plains_War "Central
Plains War"). In 1931, an [increasingly
militaristic](/wiki/Statism_in_Sh%C5%8Dwa_Japan "Statism in Shōwa Japan")
[Empire of Japan](/wiki/Empire_of_Japan "Empire of Japan"), which had long
sought influence in China[28] as the first step of what its government saw as
the country's [right to rule Asia](/wiki/Hakko_ichiu "Hakko ichiu"), used the
[Mukden Incident](/wiki/Mukden_Incident "Mukden Incident") as a pretext to
[launch an invasion of Manchuria](/wiki/Japanese_invasion_of_Manchuria
"Japanese invasion of Manchuria") and establish the [puppet
state](/wiki/Puppet_state "Puppet state") of [Manchukuo](/wiki/Manchukuo
"Manchukuo").[29]

Too weak to resist Japan, China appealed to the [League of
Nations](/wiki/League_of_Nations "League of Nations") for help. Japan withdrew
from the League of Nations after being [condemned](/wiki/Lytton_Report "Lytton
Report") for its incursion into Manchuria. The two nations then fought several
battles, in [Shanghai](/wiki/28_January_Incident "28 January Incident"),
[Rehe](/wiki/Battle_of_Rehe "Battle of Rehe") and
[Hebei](/wiki/Defense_of_the_Great_Wall "Defense of the Great Wall"), until
the [Tanggu Truce](/wiki/Tanggu_Truce "Tanggu Truce") was signed in 1933.
Thereafter, Chinese volunteer forces continued the resistance to Japanese
aggression in [Manchuria](/wiki/Pacification_of_Manchukuo "Pacification of
Manchukuo"), and [Chahar and
Suiyuan](/wiki/Actions_in_Inner_Mongolia_\(1933%E2%80%931936\) "Actions in
Inner Mongolia \(1933–1936\)").[30] After the 1936 [Xi'an
Incident](/wiki/Xi%27an_Incident "Xi'an Incident"), the Kuomintang and
communist forces agreed on a ceasefire to present a [united
front](/wiki/Second_United_Front "Second United Front") to oppose Japan.[31]

## Pre-war events

### Italian invasion of Ethiopia (1935)

Main article: [Second Italo-Ethiopian War](/wiki/Second_Italo-Ethiopian_War
"Second Italo-Ethiopian War")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Soldatietiopia.jpg/220px-
Soldatietiopia.jpg)](/wiki/File:Soldatietiopia.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Soldatietiopia.jpg "Enlarge")

Italian soldiers recruited in 1935, on their way to fight the [Second Italo-
Abyssinian War](/wiki/Second_Italo-Abyssinian_War "Second Italo-Abyssinian
War")

The Second Italo–Abyssinian War was a brief [colonial war](/wiki/Colonial_war
"Colonial war") that began in October 1935 and ended in May 1936. The war
began with the invasion of the [Ethiopian Empire](/wiki/Ethiopian_Empire
"Ethiopian Empire") (also known as [Abyssinia](/wiki/Names_of_Ethiopia "Names
of Ethiopia")) by the armed forces of the [Kingdom of
Italy](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy "Kingdom of Italy") (_Regno d 'Italia_), which
was launched from [Italian Somaliland](/wiki/Italian_Somaliland "Italian
Somaliland") and [Eritrea](/wiki/Italian_Eritrea "Italian Eritrea").[32] The
war resulted in the [military occupation](/wiki/Military_occupation "Military
occupation") of Ethiopia and its [annexation](/wiki/Annexation "Annexation")
into the newly created colony of [Italian East
Africa](/wiki/Italian_East_Africa "Italian East Africa") (_Africa Orientale
Italiana_ , or AOI); in addition it exposed the weakness of the [League of
Nations](/wiki/League_of_Nations "League of Nations") as a force to preserve
peace. Both Italy and Ethiopia were member nations, but the League did nothing
when the former clearly violated the League's [Article
X](/wiki/Article_X_of_the_Covenant_of_the_League_of_Nations "Article X of the
Covenant of the League of Nations").[33] Germany was the only major European
nation to support the invasion. Italy subsequently dropped its objections to
Germany's goal of absorbing [Austria](/wiki/Federal_State_of_Austria "Federal
State of Austria").[34]

### Spanish Civil War (1936–39)

Main article: [Spanish Civil War](/wiki/Spanish_Civil_War "Spanish Civil War")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-H25224%2C_Guernica%2C_Ruinen.jpg/220px-
Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-H25224%2C_Guernica%2C_Ruinen.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-H25224,_Guernica,_Ruinen.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-H25224,_Guernica,_Ruinen.jpg "Enlarge")

The [bombing of Guernica](/wiki/Bombing_of_Guernica "Bombing of Guernica") in
1937, during the [Spanish Civil War](/wiki/Spanish_Civil_War "Spanish Civil
War"), sparked Europe-wide fears that the next war would be based on bombing
of cities with very high civilian casualties

When civil war broke out in Spain, Hitler and Mussolini lent military support
to the [Nationalist rebels](/wiki/Nationalist_faction_\(Spanish_Civil_War\)
"Nationalist faction \(Spanish Civil War\)"), led by General [Francisco
Franco](/wiki/Francisco_Franco "Francisco Franco"). The Soviet Union supported
the existing government, the [Spanish Republic](/wiki/Second_Spanish_Republic
"Second Spanish Republic"). Over 30,000 foreign volunteers, known as the
[International Brigades](/wiki/International_Brigades "International
Brigades"), also fought against the Nationalists. Both Germany and the USSR
used this [proxy war](/wiki/Proxy_war "Proxy war") as an opportunity to test
in combat their most advanced weapons and tactics. The Nationalists won the
civil war in April 1939; Franco, now dictator, remained officially neutral
during Second World War but generally favoured the Axis.[35] His greatest
collaboration with Germany was the sending of [volunteers](/wiki/Blue_Division
"Blue Division") to fight on the [Eastern
Front](/wiki/Eastern_Front_\(World_War_II\) "Eastern Front \(World War
II\)").[36]

### Japanese invasion of China (1937)

Main article: [Second Sino-Japanese War](/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War
"Second Sino-Japanese War")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Shanghai1937IJA_ruins.jpg/220px-
Shanghai1937IJA_ruins.jpg)](/wiki/File:Shanghai1937IJA_ruins.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Shanghai1937IJA_ruins.jpg "Enlarge")

[Japanese Imperial Army](/wiki/Japanese_Imperial_Army "Japanese Imperial
Army") soldiers during the [Battle of Shanghai](/wiki/Battle_of_Shanghai
"Battle of Shanghai"), 1937

In July 1937, Japan captured the former Chinese imperial capital of
[Peking](/wiki/Peking "Peking") after instigating the [Marco Polo Bridge
Incident](/wiki/Marco_Polo_Bridge_Incident "Marco Polo Bridge Incident"),
which culminated in the Japanese campaign to invade all of China.[37] The
Soviets quickly signed a [non-aggression pact with China](/wiki/Sino-
Soviet_Non-Aggression_Pact "Sino-Soviet Non-Aggression Pact") to lend
[materiel](/wiki/Materiel "Materiel") support, effectively ending China's
prior [co-operation with Germany](/wiki/Sino-
German_cooperation_1926%E2%80%931941 "Sino-German cooperation 1926–1941").
From September to November, the Japanese attacked
[Taiyuan](/wiki/Battle_of_Taiyuan "Battle of Taiyuan"),[38][39] as well as
engaging the [Kuomintang Army](/wiki/National_Revolutionary_Army "National
Revolutionary Army") [around Xinkou](/wiki/Battle_of_Xinkou "Battle of
Xinkou")[38][39] and [Communist forces](/wiki/Communist_Party_of_China
"Communist Party of China") [in Pingxingguan](/wiki/Battle_of_Pingxingguan
"Battle of Pingxingguan").[40][41] [Generalissimo](/wiki/Generalissimo
"Generalissimo") [Chiang Kai-shek](/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek "Chiang Kai-shek")
deployed his [best army](/wiki/German-
trained_divisions_in_the_National_Revolutionary_Army "German-trained divisions
in the National Revolutionary Army") to [defend
Shanghai](/wiki/Battle_of_Shanghai "Battle of Shanghai"), but, after three
months of fighting, Shanghai fell. The Japanese continued to push the Chinese
forces back, [capturing the capital Nanking](/wiki/Battle_of_Nanking "Battle
of Nanking") in December 1937. After the fall of Nanking, tens of thousands if
not hundreds of thousands of Chinese civilians and disarmed combatants were
[murdered by the Japanese](/wiki/Nanking_Massacre "Nanking Massacre").[42][43]

In March 1938, Nationalist Chinese forces won their [first major victory at
Taierzhuang](/wiki/Battle_of_Taierzhuang "Battle of Taierzhuang") but then the
city of [Xuzhou](/wiki/Xuzhou "Xuzhou") [was taken by
Japanese](/wiki/Battle_of_Xuzhou "Battle of Xuzhou") in May.[44] In June 1938,
Chinese forces stalled the Japanese advance by [flooding the Yellow
River](/wiki/1938_Yellow_River_flood "1938 Yellow River flood"); this
manoeuvre bought time for the Chinese to prepare their defences at
[Wuhan](/wiki/Wuhan "Wuhan"), but the [city was taken](/wiki/Battle_of_Wuhan
"Battle of Wuhan") by October.[45] Japanese military victories did not bring
about the collapse of Chinese resistance that Japan had hoped to achieve;
instead the Chinese government relocated inland to [Chongqing](/wiki/Chongqing
"Chongqing") and continued the war.[46][47]

### Soviet–Japanese border conflicts

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Battle_of_Lake_Khasan-
Red_Army_gunners_in_the_interval.jpg/220px-Battle_of_Lake_Khasan-
Red_Army_gunners_in_the_interval.jpg)](/wiki/File:Battle_of_Lake_Khasan-
Red_Army_gunners_in_the_interval.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Battle_of_Lake_Khasan-Red_Army_gunners_in_the_interval.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Red Army](/wiki/Red_Army "Red Army") artillery unit during the [Battle of
Lake Khasan](/wiki/Battle_of_Lake_Khasan "Battle of Lake Khasan"), 1938

Main article: [Soviet–Japanese border
conflicts](/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Japanese_border_conflicts "Soviet–Japanese
border conflicts")

In the mid-to-late 1930s, Japanese forces in [Manchukuo](/wiki/Manchukuo
"Manchukuo") had sporadic border clashes with the Soviet Union and the
[Mongolian People's Republic](/wiki/Mongolian_People%27s_Republic "Mongolian
People's Republic"). The Japanese doctrine of [Hokushin-ron](/wiki/Hokushin-
ron "Hokushin-ron"), which emphasised Japan's expansion northward, was
favoured by the Imperial Army during this time. With the Japanese defeat at
[Khalkin Gol](/wiki/Battles_of_Khalkhin_Gol "Battles of Khalkhin Gol") in
1939, the ongoing Second Sino-Japanese War[48] and ally Nazi Germany pursuing
neutrality with the Soviets, this policy would prove difficult to maintain.
Japan and the Soviet Union eventually signed a [Neutrality
Pact](/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Japanese_Neutrality_Pact "Soviet–Japanese
Neutrality Pact") in April 1941, and Japan adopted the doctrine of [Nanshin-
ron](/wiki/Nanshin-ron "Nanshin-ron"), promoted by the Navy, which took its
focus southward, eventually leading to its war with the United States and the
Western Allies.[49][50]

### European occupations and agreements

Further information: [Anschluss](/wiki/Anschluss "Anschluss"),
[Appeasement](/wiki/Appeasement "Appeasement"), [Munich
Agreement](/wiki/Munich_Agreement "Munich Agreement"), [German occupation of
Czechoslovakia](/wiki/German_occupation_of_Czechoslovakia "German occupation
of Czechoslovakia"), and [Molotov–Ribbentrop
Pact](/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact "Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-R69173%2C_M%C3%BCnchener_Abkommen%2C_Staatschefs.jpg/220px-
Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-R69173%2C_M%C3%BCnchener_Abkommen%2C_Staatschefs.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-R69173,_M%C3%BCnchener_Abkommen,_Staatschefs.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-R69173,_M%C3%BCnchener_Abkommen,_Staatschefs.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Chamberlain](/wiki/Neville_Chamberlain "Neville Chamberlain"),
[Daladier](/wiki/%C3%89douard_Daladier "Édouard Daladier"),
[Hitler](/wiki/Hitler "Hitler"), [Mussolini](/wiki/Benito_Mussolini "Benito
Mussolini"), and [Ciano](/wiki/Galeazzo_Ciano "Galeazzo Ciano") pictured just
before signing the [Munich Agreement](/wiki/Munich_Agreement "Munich
Agreement"), 29 September 1938

In Europe, Germany and Italy were becoming more aggressive. In March 1938,
Germany [annexed Austria](/wiki/Anschluss "Anschluss"), again provoking
[little response](/wiki/Appeasement_of_Hitler "Appeasement of Hitler") from
other European powers.[51] Encouraged, Hitler began pressing German claims on
the [Sudetenland](/wiki/Sudetenland "Sudetenland"), an area of
[Czechoslovakia](/wiki/Czechoslovakia "Czechoslovakia") with a predominantly
[ethnic German](/wiki/Ethnic_German "Ethnic German") population; and soon
Britain and France followed the counsel of British Prime Minister [Neville
Chamberlain](/wiki/Neville_Chamberlain "Neville Chamberlain") and conceded
this territory to Germany in the [Munich Agreement](/wiki/Munich_Agreement
"Munich Agreement"), which was made against the wishes of the Czechoslovak
government, in exchange for a promise of no further territorial demands.[52]
Soon afterwards, Germany and Italy forced Czechoslovakia to [cede additional
territory](/wiki/First_Vienna_Award "First Vienna Award") to
[Hungary](/wiki/Hungary "Hungary") and Poland annexed Czechoslovakia's
[Zaolzie](/wiki/Zaolzie "Zaolzie") region.[53]

Although all of Germany's stated demands had been satisfied by the agreement,
privately Hitler was furious that British interference had prevented him from
seizing all of Czechoslovakia in one operation. In subsequent speeches Hitler
attacked British and Jewish "war-mongers" and in January 1939 [secretly
ordered a major build-up of the German navy](/wiki/Plan_Z "Plan Z") to
challenge British naval supremacy. In March 1939, [Germany invaded the
remainder of Czechoslovakia](/wiki/German_occupation_of_Czechoslovakia "German
occupation of Czechoslovakia") and subsequently split it into the German
[Protectorate of Bohemia and
Moravia](/wiki/Protectorate_of_Bohemia_and_Moravia "Protectorate of Bohemia
and Moravia") and a pro-German [client state](/wiki/Client_state "Client
state"), the [Slovak Republic](/wiki/Slovak_Republic_\(1939%E2%80%931945\)
"Slovak Republic \(1939–1945\)").[54] Hitler also delivered [an
ultimatum](/wiki/1939_German_ultimatum_to_Lithuania "1939 German ultimatum to
Lithuania") to Lithuania, forcing the concession of the [Klaipėda
Region](/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da_Region "Klaipėda Region").

Greatly alarmed and with Hitler making further demands on the [Free City of
Danzig](/wiki/Free_City_of_Danzig "Free City of Danzig"), Britain and France
[guaranteed their support for Polish independence](/wiki/Anglo-
Polish_military_alliance#British_Guarantee_to_Poland "Anglo-Polish military
alliance"); when [Italy conquered Albania](/wiki/Italian_invasion_of_Albania
"Italian invasion of Albania") in April 1939, the same guarantee was extended
to Romania and [Greece](/wiki/Greece "Greece").[55] Shortly after the
[Franco](/wiki/Franco-Polish_Military_Alliance "Franco-Polish Military
Alliance")-British pledge to Poland, Germany and Italy formalised their own
alliance with the [Pact of Steel](/wiki/Pact_of_Steel "Pact of Steel").[56]
Hitler accused Britain and Poland of trying to "encircle" Germany and
renounced the [Anglo-German Naval Agreement](/wiki/Anglo-
German_Naval_Agreement "Anglo-German Naval Agreement") and the [German–Polish
Non-Aggression Pact](/wiki/German%E2%80%93Polish_Non-Aggression_Pact
"German–Polish Non-Aggression Pact").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-H27337%2C_Moskau%2C_Stalin_und_Ribbentrop_im_Kreml.jpg/170px-
Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-H27337%2C_Moskau%2C_Stalin_und_Ribbentrop_im_Kreml.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-H27337,_Moskau,_Stalin_und_Ribbentrop_im_Kreml.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-H27337,_Moskau,_Stalin_und_Ribbentrop_im_Kreml.jpg
"Enlarge")

German Foreign Minister [Joachim von Ribbentrop](/wiki/Joachim_von_Ribbentrop
"Joachim von Ribbentrop") (right) and the Soviet leader [Joseph
Stalin](/wiki/Joseph_Stalin "Joseph Stalin"), after signing the
[Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact](/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact
"Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact"), 23 August 1939

In August 1939, Germany and the Soviet Union signed the [Molotov–Ribbentrop
Pact](/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact "Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact"),[57] a
non-aggression treaty with a secret protocol. The parties gave each other
rights to "spheres of influence" (western
[Poland](/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic "Second Polish Republic") and
[Lithuania](/wiki/Lithuania "Lithuania") for Germany; [eastern
Poland](/wiki/Territories_of_Poland_annexed_by_the_Soviet_Union "Territories
of Poland annexed by the Soviet Union"), Finland, [Estonia](/wiki/Estonia
"Estonia"), Latvia and [Bessarabia](/wiki/Bessarabia "Bessarabia") for the
USSR). It also raised the question of continuing Polish independence.[58] The
agreement was crucial to Hitler because it assured that Germany would not have
to face the prospect of a two-front war, as it had in World War I, after it
defeated Poland.

The situation reached a general crisis in late August as German troops
continued to mobilise against the Polish border. In a private meeting with the
Italian foreign minister, [Count Ciano](/wiki/Count_Ciano "Count Ciano"),
Hitler asserted that Poland was a "doubtful neutral" that needed to either
yield to his demands or be "liquidated" to prevent it from drawing off German
troops in the future "unavoidable" war with the Western democracies. He did
not believe Britain or France would intervene in the conflict.[59] On 23
August Hitler ordered the attack to proceed on 26 August, but upon hearing
that Britain had concluded a formal mutual assistance pact with Poland and
that Italy would maintain neutrality, he decided to delay it.[60]

In response to British requests for direct negotiations to avoid war, Germany
made demands on Poland, which only served as a pretext to worsen
relations.[61] On 29 August, Hitler demanded that a Polish
[plenipotentiary](/wiki/Plenipotentiary "Plenipotentiary") immediately travel
to Berlin to negotiate the handover of [Danzig](/wiki/Danzig "Danzig"), and to
allow a [plebiscite](/wiki/Plebiscite "Plebiscite") in the [Polish
Corridor](/wiki/Polish_Corridor "Polish Corridor") in which the German
minority would vote on secession.[61] The Poles refused to comply with the
German demands and on the night of 30–31 August in a violent meeting with the
British ambassador [Neville Henderson](/wiki/Neville_Henderson "Neville
Henderson"), Ribbentrop declared that Germany considered its claims
rejected.[62]

## Course of the war

Further information: [Diplomatic history of World War
II](/wiki/Diplomatic_history_of_World_War_II "Diplomatic history of World War
II")

### War breaks out in Europe (1939–40)

Main articles: [Invasion of Poland](/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland "Invasion of
Poland"), [Phoney War](/wiki/Phoney_War "Phoney War"), [Occupation of Poland
(1939–45)](/wiki/Occupation_of_Poland_\(1939%E2%80%9345\) "Occupation of
Poland \(1939–45\)"), [Nazi crimes against the Polish
nation](/wiki/Nazi_crimes_against_the_Polish_nation "Nazi crimes against the
Polish nation"), [Soviet invasion of Poland](/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Poland
"Soviet invasion of Poland"), and [Soviet repressions of Polish citizens
(1939–1946)](/wiki/Soviet_repressions_of_Polish_citizens_\(1939%E2%80%931946\)
"Soviet repressions of Polish citizens \(1939–1946\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Germans_at_Polish_Border_%281939-09-01%29.jpg/220px-
Germans_at_Polish_Border_%281939-09-01%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Germans_at_Polish_Border_\(1939-09-01\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Germans_at_Polish_Border_\(1939-09-01\).jpg "Enlarge")

Soldiers of the German [Wehrmacht](/wiki/Wehrmacht "Wehrmacht") tearing down
the border crossing between [Poland](/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic "Second
Polish Republic") and the [Free City of Danzig](/wiki/Free_City_of_Danzig
"Free City of Danzig"), 1 September 1939

On 1 September 1939, Germany [invaded Poland](/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland
"Invasion of Poland") under the false pretext that the Poles had carried out a
series of [sabotage operations](/wiki/Gleiwitz_incident "Gleiwitz incident")
against German targets near the border.[63] Two days later, on 3 September,
after a British ultimatum to Germany to cease military operations was ignored,
Britain and France, followed by the fully independent
[Dominions](/wiki/Dominion "Dominion")[64] of the [British
Commonwealth](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations "Commonwealth of
Nations")[65]—[Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia") (3 September),
[Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada") (10 September), [New
Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New Zealand") (3 September), and [South
Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa") (6 September)—declared war on
Germany. However, initially the alliance provided [limited direct military
support](/wiki/Phoney_War "Phoney War") to Poland, consisting of a [cautious,
half-hearted French probe into the Saarland](/wiki/Saar_Offensive "Saar
Offensive").[66] The [Western Allies](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of
World War II") also began a [naval blockade of
Germany](/wiki/Blockade_of_Germany_\(1939%E2%80%9345\) "Blockade of Germany
\(1939–45\)"), which aimed to damage the country's economy and war effort.[67]
Germany responded by ordering [U-boat
warfare](/wiki/Submarine_warfare#World_War_II "Submarine warfare") against
Allied merchant and warships, which was to later escalate into the [Battle of
the Atlantic](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Atlantic "Battle of the Atlantic").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Bundesarchiv_Bild_146-1976-071-36%2C_Polen%2C_an_der_Brahe%2C_deutsche_Panzer.jpg/220px-
Bundesarchiv_Bild_146-1976-071-36%2C_Polen%2C_an_der_Brahe%2C_deutsche_Panzer.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_146-1976-071-36,_Polen,_an_der_Brahe,_deutsche_Panzer.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_146-1976-071-36,_Polen,_an_der_Brahe,_deutsche_Panzer.jpg
"Enlarge")

German tanks near the city of [Bydgoszcz](/wiki/Bydgoszcz "Bydgoszcz"), during
the [Invasion of Poland](/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland "Invasion of Poland")
September, 1939

On 17 September 1939, after signing a [cease-fire with
Japan](/wiki/Battles_of_Khalkhin_Gol "Battles of Khalkhin Gol"), the [Soviets
invaded Poland](/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Poland "Soviet invasion of Poland")
from the east.[68] The Polish army was defeated and [Warsaw
surrendered](/wiki/Battle_of_Warsaw_\(1939\) "Battle of Warsaw \(1939\)") to
the Germans on 27 September with final pockets of resistance surrendering on 6
October. Poland's territory was divided between
[Germany](/wiki/Polish_areas_annexed_by_Nazi_Germany "Polish areas annexed by
Nazi Germany") and the [Soviet
Union](/wiki/Territories_of_Poland_annexed_by_the_Soviet_Union "Territories of
Poland annexed by the Soviet Union"), with
[Lithuania](/wiki/Territorial_changes_of_Poland#World_War_II "Territorial
changes of Poland") and [Slovakia](/wiki/Slovak_invasion_of_Poland_\(1939\)
"Slovak invasion of Poland \(1939\)") also receiving small shares. After the
defeat of Poland's armed forces, the Polish resistance established an
[Underground State](/wiki/Polish_Underground_State "Polish Underground State")
and a partisan [Home Army](/wiki/Home_Army "Home Army").[69] About 100,000
Polish military personnel were [evacuated to
Romania](/wiki/Romanian_Bridgehead "Romanian Bridgehead") and the Baltic
countries; many of these soldiers later fought against the Germans in other
theatres of the war.[70] [Poland's Enigma
codebreakers](/wiki/Biuro_Szyfr%C3%B3w "Biuro Szyfrów") were also evacuated to
France.[71]

On 6 October, Hitler made a public peace overture to Britain and France, but
said that the future of Poland was to be determined exclusively by Germany and
the Soviet Union. Chamberlain rejected this on 12 October, saying "Past
experience has shown that no reliance can be placed upon the promises of the
present German Government."[62] After this rejection Hitler ordered an
immediate offensive against France,[72] but bad weather forced repeated
postponements until the spring of 1940.[73][74][75]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Spotkanie_Sojusznik%C3%B3w.jpg/220px-
Spotkanie_Sojusznik%C3%B3w.jpg)](/wiki/File:Spotkanie_Sojusznik%C3%B3w.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Spotkanie_Sojusznik%C3%B3w.jpg "Enlarge")

German and Soviet army officers pictured shaking hands—after [Nazi
Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany") and [Soviet
Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") annexed new territories in [Eastern
Europe](/wiki/Eastern_Europe "Eastern Europe"), 1939

After signing the [German–Soviet Treaty of Friendship, Cooperation and
Demarcation](/wiki/German%E2%80%93Soviet_Frontier_Treaty "German–Soviet
Frontier Treaty"), the Soviet Union forced the [Baltic
countries](/wiki/Baltic_states "Baltic states")—Estonia, Latvia and
Lithuania—to allow it [to station Soviet troops in their countries under pacts
of "mutual
assistance"](/wiki/Occupation_of_Baltic_states#Ultimatums_to_Estonia.2C_Latvia.2C_Lithuania
"Occupation of Baltic states").[76][77][78] Finland rejected territorial
demands, prompting a Soviet invasion in November 1939.[79] The resulting
[Winter War](/wiki/Winter_War "Winter War") ended in March 1940 with [Finnish
concessions](/wiki/Moscow_Peace_Treaty "Moscow Peace Treaty").[80] Britain and
France, treating the Soviet attack on Finland as tantamount to its entering
the war on the side of the Germans, responded to the Soviet invasion by
supporting the USSR's expulsion from the League of Nations.[78]

In June 1940, the Soviet Union forcibly annexed [Estonia, Latvia and
Lithuania](/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_the_Baltic_states_\(1940\) "Soviet
occupation of the Baltic states \(1940\)"),[77] and the disputed Romanian
regions of [Bessarabia, Northern Bukovina and
Hertza](/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_Bessarabia_and_Northern_Bukovina "Soviet
occupation of Bessarabia and Northern Bukovina"). Meanwhile, Nazi-Soviet
political rapprochement and economic co-operation[81][82] gradually
stalled,[83][_[page needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing
sources")_][84] and both states began preparations for war.[85]

### Western Europe (1940–41)

Main article: [Western Front (World War
II)](/wiki/Western_Front_\(World_War_II\) "Western Front \(World War II\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Maginot_Line_ln-
en_svg.svg/330px-Maginot_Line_ln-en_svg.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Maginot_Line_ln-
en_svg.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Maginot_Line_ln-en_svg.svg "Enlarge")

Map of the French [Maginot Line](/wiki/Maginot_Line "Maginot Line")

In April 1940, [Germany invaded Denmark and
Norway](/wiki/Operation_Weser%C3%BCbung "Operation Weserübung") to protect
shipments of [iron ore from Sweden](/wiki/Swedish_iron-
ore_mining_during_World_War_II "Swedish iron-ore mining during World War II"),
which the Allies were [attempting to cut off](/wiki/Operation_Wilfred
"Operation Wilfred") by unilaterally mining neutral Norwegian waters.[86]
[Denmark](/wiki/Denmark "Denmark") capitulated after a few hours, and [despite
Allied support](/wiki/Norwegian_Campaign "Norwegian Campaign"), during which
the important harbour of [Narvik](/wiki/Narvik "Narvik") temporarily was
recaptured from the Germans, [Norway](/wiki/Norway "Norway") was conquered
within two months.[87] [British discontent over the Norwegian
campaign](/wiki/Norway_Debate "Norway Debate") led to the replacement of the
British Prime Minister, [Neville Chamberlain](/wiki/Neville_Chamberlain
"Neville Chamberlain"), with [Winston Churchill](/wiki/Winston_Churchill
"Winston Churchill") on 10 May 1940.[88]

Germany [launched an offensive against France](/wiki/Battle_of_France "Battle
of France") and, adhering to the [Manstein Plan](/wiki/Manstein_Plan "Manstein
Plan") also attacked the neutral nations of [Belgium](/wiki/Battle_of_Belgium
"Battle of Belgium"), [the Netherlands](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Netherlands
"Battle of the Netherlands"), and
[Luxembourg](/wiki/German_invasion_of_Luxembourg "German invasion of
Luxembourg") on 10 May 1940.[89] That same day British forces landed in
[Iceland](/wiki/Invasion_of_Iceland "Invasion of Iceland") and the
[Faroes](/wiki/British_occupation_of_the_Faroe_Islands "British occupation of
the Faroe Islands") to preempt a possible German invasion of the islands.[90]
The U.S., in close co-operation with [the Danish envoy to Washington
D.C.](/wiki/Henrik_Kauffmann "Henrik Kauffmann"), agreed to protect
[Greenland](/wiki/Greenland_in_World_War_II "Greenland in World War II"),
laying the political framework for the formal establishment of bases in April
1941. The [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands_in_World_War_II "Netherlands in
World War II") and [Belgium](/wiki/Belgium_in_World_War_II "Belgium in World
War II") were overrun using [blitzkrieg](/wiki/Blitzkrieg "Blitzkrieg")
tactics in a few days and weeks, respectively.[91] The French-fortified
[Maginot Line](/wiki/Maginot_Line "Maginot Line") and the main body of the
Allied forces which had moved into Belgium were circumvented by a flanking
movement through the thickly wooded [Ardennes](/wiki/Ardennes "Ardennes")
region,[92] mistakenly perceived by Allied planners as an impenetrable natural
barrier against armoured vehicles.[93][94] As a result, the bulk of the Allied
armies found themselves trapped in an encirclement and were beaten. The
majority were taken prisoner, whilst over 300,000, mostly British and French,
were [evacuated from the continent at Dunkirk](/wiki/Dunkirk_evacuation
"Dunkirk evacuation") by early June, although abandoning almost all of their
equipment.[95]

On 10 June, [Italy invaded France](/wiki/Italian_invasion_of_France "Italian
invasion of France"), declaring war on both France and the United Kingdom.[96]
Paris fell to the Germans on 14 June and eight days later [France signed an
armistice with Germany](/wiki/Armistice_of_22_June_1940 "Armistice of 22 June
1940") and was soon divided into
[German](/wiki/German_military_administration_in_occupied_France_during_World_War_II
"German military administration in occupied France during World War II") and
[Italian occupation zones](/wiki/Italian_occupation_of_France "Italian
occupation of France"),[97] and an unoccupied [rump state](/wiki/Rump_state
"Rump state") under the [Vichy Regime](/wiki/Vichy_Regime "Vichy Regime"),
which, though officially neutral, was generally aligned with Germany. France
kept its fleet but the British feared the Germans would seize it, so on 3
July, the British [attacked it](/wiki/Attack_on_Mers-el-K%C3%A9bir "Attack on
Mers-el-Kébir").[98]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/View_from_St_Paul%27s_Cathedral_after_the_Blitz.jpg/220px-
View_from_St_Paul%27s_Cathedral_after_the_Blitz.jpg)](/wiki/File:View_from_St_Paul%27s_Cathedral_after_the_Blitz.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:View_from_St_Paul%27s_Cathedral_after_the_Blitz.jpg "Enlarge")

View of [London](/wiki/London "London") after the German
[_Blitz_](/wiki/The_Blitz "The Blitz"), 29 December 1940

The [Battle of Britain](/wiki/Battle_of_Britain "Battle of Britain")[99] began
in early July with [Luftwaffe attacks on shipping and
harbours](/wiki/Kanalkampf "Kanalkampf").[100] On 19 July, Hitler again
publicly offered to end the war, saying he had no desire to destroy the
[British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire"). The United Kingdom
rejected this ultimatum.[101] The main [German air superiority
campaign](/wiki/Adlertag "Adlertag") started in August but failed to defeat
[RAF Fighter Command](/wiki/RAF_Fighter_Command "RAF Fighter Command"), and a
[proposed invasion](/wiki/Operation_Sea_Lion "Operation Sea Lion") was
postponed indefinitely on 17 September. The German [strategic
bombing](/wiki/Strategic_bombing "Strategic bombing") offensive intensified as
night attacks on London and other cities in [the Blitz](/wiki/The_Blitz "The
Blitz"), but largely failed to disrupt the British war effort.[100]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Heinkel_He_111_during_the_Battle_of_Britain.jpg/220px-
Heinkel_He_111_during_the_Battle_of_Britain.jpg)](/wiki/File:Heinkel_He_111_during_the_Battle_of_Britain.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Heinkel_He_111_during_the_Battle_of_Britain.jpg "Enlarge")

German [Luftwaffe](/wiki/Luftwaffe "Luftwaffe"), [Heinkel He
111](/wiki/Heinkel_He_111 "Heinkel He 111") bombers during the [Battle of
Britain](/wiki/Battle_of_Britain "Battle of Britain")

Using newly captured French ports, the German Navy [enjoyed
success](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Atlantic#.27Happy_Time.27_.28June_1940_.E2.80.93_February_1941.29
"Battle of the Atlantic") against an over-extended [Royal
Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy "Royal Navy"), using [U-boats](/wiki/U-boat "U-boat")
against British shipping in the [Atlantic](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Atlantic
"Battle of the Atlantic").[102] The British scored a significant victory on 27
May 1941 by [sinking the German battleship
_Bismarck_](/wiki/Last_battle_of_the_battleship_Bismarck "Last battle of the
battleship Bismarck").[103] Perhaps most importantly, during the Battle of
Britain the [Royal Air Force](/wiki/Royal_Air_Force "Royal Air Force") had
successfully resisted the Luftwaffe's assault, and the German bombing campaign
largely ended in May 1941.[104]

Throughout this period, the neutral United States took measures to assist
China and the Western Allies. In November 1939, the American [Neutrality
Act](/wiki/Neutrality_Acts_of_1930s "Neutrality Acts of 1930s") was amended to
allow ["cash and carry"](/wiki/Cash_and_carry_\(World_War_II\) "Cash and carry
\(World War II\)") purchases by the Allies.[105] In 1940, following the German
capture of Paris, the size of the [United States
Navy](/wiki/United_States_Navy "United States Navy") was [significantly
increased](/wiki/Two-Ocean_Navy_Act "Two-Ocean Navy Act"). In September, the
United States further agreed to a [trade of American destroyers for British
bases](/wiki/Destroyers_for_Bases_Agreement "Destroyers for Bases
Agreement").[106] Still, a large majority of the American public continued to
oppose any direct military intervention into the conflict well into 1941.[107]

Although Roosevelt had promised to keep the United States out of the war, he
nevertheless took concrete steps to prepare for war. In December 1940 he
accused Hitler of planning world conquest and ruled out negotiations as
useless, calling for the US to become an "[arsenal of
democracy](/wiki/Arsenal_of_Democracy "Arsenal of Democracy")" and promoted
the passage of [Lend-Lease](/wiki/Lend-Lease "Lend-Lease") aid to support the
British war effort.[101] In January 1941 secret high level staff talks with
the British began for the purposes of determining how to defeat Germany should
the US enter the war. They decided on a number of offensive policies,
including an air offensive, the "early elimination" of Italy, raids, support
of resistance groups, and the capture of positions to launch an offensive
against Germany.[108]

At the end of September 1940, the [Tripartite Pact](/wiki/Tripartite_Pact
"Tripartite Pact") united Japan, Italy and Germany to formalise the [Axis
Powers](/wiki/Axis_Powers "Axis Powers"). The Tripartite Pact stipulated that
any country, with the exception of the Soviet Union, not in the war which
attacked any Axis Power would be forced to go to war against all three.[109]
The Axis expanded in November 1940 when Hungary, Slovakia and
[Romania](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Romania "Kingdom of Romania") joined the Tripartite
Pact.[110] Romania would make a [major
contribution](/wiki/Romania_in_World_War_II "Romania in World War II") (as
[did Hungary](/wiki/Hungary_in_World_War_II "Hungary in World War II")) to the
Axis war against the USSR, partially to recapture [territory ceded to the
USSR](/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_Bessarabia_and_Northern_Bukovina "Soviet
occupation of Bessarabia and Northern Bukovina"), partially to pursue its
leader [Ion Antonescu](/wiki/Ion_Antonescu "Ion Antonescu")'s desire to combat
communism.[111]

### Mediterranean (1940–41)

Main article: [Mediterranean and Middle East theatre of World War
II](/wiki/Mediterranean_and_Middle_East_theatre_of_World_War_II "Mediterranean
and Middle East theatre of World War II")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/9_Div_Tobruk%28AWM_020779%29.jpg/220px-9_Div_Tobruk%28AWM_020779%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:9_Div_Tobruk\(AWM_020779\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:9_Div_Tobruk\(AWM_020779\).jpg "Enlarge")

Soldiers of the [British Commonwealth
forces](/wiki/British_Empire_in_World_War_II "British Empire in World War II")
from the Australian Army's [9th Division](/wiki/9th_Division_\(Australia\)
"9th Division \(Australia\)") during the [Siege of
Tobruk](/wiki/Siege_of_Tobruk "Siege of Tobruk"); [North African
Campaign](/wiki/North_African_Campaign "North African Campaign"), August 1941

Italy began operations in the Mediterranean, initiating a [siege of
Malta](/wiki/Siege_of_Malta_\(World_War_II\) "Siege of Malta \(World War
II\)") in June, [conquering British
Somaliland](/wiki/Italian_conquest_of_British_Somaliland "Italian conquest of
British Somaliland") in August, and [making an incursion into British-held
Egypt](/wiki/Italian_invasion_of_Egypt "Italian invasion of Egypt") in
September 1940. In October 1940, Italy started the [Greco-Italian
War](/wiki/Greco-Italian_War "Greco-Italian War") because of Mussolini's
jealousy of Hitler's success but within days was repulsed with few territorial
gains and a stalemate soon occurred.[112] The United Kingdom responded to
Greek requests for assistance by sending troops to Crete and providing air
support to Greece. Hitler decided that when the weather improved he would take
action against Greece to assist the Italians and prevent the British from
gaining a foothold in the Balkans, to strike against the British naval
dominance of the Mediterranean, and to secure his hold on Romanian oil.[113]

In December 1940, British Commonwealth forces began counter-offensives against
[Italian forces in Egypt](/wiki/Operation_Compass "Operation Compass") and
[Italian East
Africa](/wiki/East_African_Campaign_\(World_War_II\)#Allied_counter-offensive
"East African Campaign \(World War II\)").[114] The offensive in North Africa
was highly successful and by early February 1941 Italy had lost control of
eastern Libya and large numbers of Italian troops had been taken prisoner. The
[Italian Navy](/wiki/Regia_Marina "Regia Marina") also suffered significant
defeats, with the Royal Navy putting three Italian battleships out of
commission by a [carrier attack at Taranto](/wiki/Battle_of_Taranto "Battle of
Taranto"), and neutralising several more warships at the [Battle of Cape
Matapan](/wiki/Battle_of_Cape_Matapan "Battle of Cape Matapan").[115]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/E_003743_E.jpg/220px-
E_003743_E.jpg)](/wiki/File:E_003743_E.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:E_003743_E.jpg "Enlarge")

Captured German [Afrika Korps](/wiki/Afrika_Korps "Afrika Korps") soldiers,
December 1941

The Germans soon intervened to assist Italy. Hitler [sent German forces to
Libya](/wiki/Operation_Sonnenblume "Operation Sonnenblume") in February, and
by the end of March the Axis had [launched an
offensive](/wiki/Axis_desert_offensive_\(1941\) "Axis desert offensive
\(1941\)") which drove back the Commonwealth forces which had been weakened to
support Greece.[116] In under a month, Commonwealth forces were pushed back
into Egypt with the exception of the [besieged port of
Tobruk](/wiki/Siege_of_Tobruk "Siege of Tobruk") that fell later.[117] The
Commonwealth [attempted to dislodge Axis forces in
May](/wiki/Operation_Brevity "Operation Brevity") and [again in
June](/wiki/Operation_Battleaxe "Operation Battleaxe"), but failed on both
occasions.[118]

By late March 1941, following [Bulgaria](/wiki/Bulgaria "Bulgaria")'s signing
of the [Tripartite Pact](/wiki/Tripartite_Pact "Tripartite Pact"), the Germans
were in position to intervene in Greece. Plans were changed, however, because
of developments in neighbouring [Yugoslavia](/wiki/Yugoslavia "Yugoslavia").
The Yugoslav government had signed the Tripartite Pact on 25 March, only to be
overthrown two days later by a [British-encouraged
coup](/wiki/Yugoslav_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat "Yugoslav coup d'état"). Hitler viewed
the new regime as hostile and immediately decided to eliminate it. On 6 April
Germany simultaneously invaded both [Yugoslavia](/wiki/Invasion_of_Yugoslavia
"Invasion of Yugoslavia") and [Greece](/wiki/Battle_of_Greece "Battle of
Greece"), making rapid progress and forcing both nations to surrender within
the month. The British were driven from the Balkans after Germany [conquered
the Greek island of Crete](/wiki/Battle_of_Crete "Battle of Crete") by the end
of May.[119] Although the Axis victory was swift, bitter partisan warfare
subsequently broke out against the [Axis occupation of
Yugoslavia](/wiki/Axis_occupation_of_Yugoslavia "Axis occupation of
Yugoslavia"), which continued until the end of the war.

The Allies did have some successes during this time. In the Middle East,
Commonwealth forces first [quashed an uprising in Iraq](/wiki/Anglo-Iraqi_War
"Anglo-Iraqi War") which had been supported by German aircraft from bases
within Vichy-controlled [Syria](/wiki/French_Mandate_of_Syria "French Mandate
of Syria"),[120] then, with the assistance of the [Free
French](/wiki/Free_French "Free French"), [invaded Syria and
Lebanon](/wiki/Syria%E2%80%93Lebanon_Campaign "Syria–Lebanon Campaign") to
prevent further such occurrences.[121]

### Axis attack on the USSR (1941)

Main articles: [Eastern Front (World War
II)](/wiki/Eastern_Front_\(World_War_II\) "Eastern Front \(World War II\)"),
[Operation Barbarossa](/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa "Operation Barbarossa"),
[Einsatzgruppen](/wiki/Einsatzgruppen "Einsatzgruppen"), [World War II
casualties of the Soviet
Union](/wiki/World_War_II_casualties_of_the_Soviet_Union "World War II
casualties of the Soviet Union"), and [German mistreatment of Soviet prisoners
of war](/wiki/German_mistreatment_of_Soviet_prisoners_of_war "German
mistreatment of Soviet prisoners of war")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/19/Second_world_war_europe_animation_small.gif)](/wiki/File:Second_world_war_europe_animation_small.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Second_world_war_europe_animation_small.gif "Enlarge")

[European theatre of World War II](/wiki/European_theatre_of_World_War_II
"European theatre of World War II") animation map, 1939–1945 — Red: [Western
Allies](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II") and Soviet
Union after 1941; Green: [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union")
before 1941; Blue: [Axis Powers](/wiki/Axis_Powers "Axis Powers")

With the situation in Europe and Asia relatively stable, Germany, Japan, and
the Soviet Union made preparations. With the Soviets wary of mounting tensions
with Germany and the Japanese planning to take advantage of the European War
by seizing resource-rich European possessions in [Southeast
Asia](/wiki/Southeast_Asia "Southeast Asia"), the two powers signed the
[Soviet–Japanese Neutrality
Pact](/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Japanese_Neutrality_Pact "Soviet–Japanese
Neutrality Pact") in April 1941.[122] By contrast, the Germans were steadily
making preparations for an attack on the Soviet Union, massing forces on the
Soviet border.[123]

Hitler believed that Britain's refusal to end the war was based on the hope
that the United States and the Soviet Union would enter the war against
Germany sooner or later.[124] He therefore decided to try to strengthen
Germany's relations with the Soviets, or failing that, to attack and eliminate
them as a factor. In November 1940, [negotiations took
place](/wiki/German%E2%80%93Soviet_Axis_talks "German–Soviet Axis talks") to
determine if the Soviet Union would join the Tripartite Pact. The Soviets
showed some interest, but asked for concessions from Finland, Bulgaria,
Turkey, and Japan that Germany considered unacceptable. On 18 December 1940,
Hitler issued the directive to prepare for an invasion of the Soviet Union.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/German_troops_in_Russia%2C_1941_-_NARA_-_540155.jpg/220px-
German_troops_in_Russia%2C_1941_-_NARA_-_540155.jpg)](/wiki/File:German_troops_in_Russia,_1941_-_NARA_-_540155.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:German_troops_in_Russia,_1941_-_NARA_-_540155.jpg "Enlarge")

German soldiers during the invasion of the Soviet Union by the [Axis
powers](/wiki/Axis_powers "Axis powers"), 1941

On 22 June 1941, Germany, supported by Italy and Romania, invaded the Soviet
Union in [Operation Barbarossa](/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa "Operation
Barbarossa"), with Germany accusing the Soviets of plotting against them. They
were joined shortly by Finland and Hungary.[125] The primary targets of this
surprise offensive[126][_[page needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources
"Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] were the [Baltic region](/wiki/Baltic_region
"Baltic region"), Moscow and [Ukraine](/wiki/Ukraine "Ukraine"), with the
[ultimate goal](/wiki/Strategic_goal_\(military\) "Strategic goal
\(military\)") of ending the 1941 campaign near the [Arkhangelsk-Astrakhan
line](/wiki/A-A_line "A-A line"), from the [Caspian](/wiki/Caspian_sea
"Caspian sea") to the [White Seas](/wiki/White_Sea "White Sea"). Hitler's
objectives were to eliminate the Soviet Union as a military power, exterminate
Communism, generate _[Lebensraum](/wiki/Lebensraum "Lebensraum")_ ("living
space")[127] by [dispossessing the native population](/wiki/Generalplan_Ost
"Generalplan Ost")[128][_[page needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources
"Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] and guarantee access to the strategic resources
needed to defeat Germany's remaining rivals.[129][_[page
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]

Although the [Red Army](/wiki/Red_Army "Red Army") was preparing for strategic
[counter-offensives](/wiki/Counter-offensive "Counter-offensive") before the
war,[130][_[page needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing
sources")_] _Barbarossa_ forced the [Soviet supreme command](/wiki/Stavka
"Stavka") to adopt a [strategic defence](/wiki/Strategic_defence "Strategic
defence"). During the summer, the Axis made significant gains into Soviet
territory, inflicting immense losses in both personnel and materiel. By the
middle of August, however, the German [Army High
Command](/wiki/Oberkommando_des_Heeres "Oberkommando des Heeres") decided to
[suspend the offensive](/wiki/Battle_of_Smolensk_\(1941\) "Battle of Smolensk
\(1941\)") of a considerably depleted [Army Group
Centre](/wiki/Army_Group_Centre "Army Group Centre"), and to divert the [2nd
Panzer Group](/wiki/2nd_Panzer_Group "2nd Panzer Group") to reinforce troops
advancing towards central Ukraine and Leningrad.[131][_[page
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] The [Kiev
offensive](/wiki/Battle_of_Kiev_\(1941\) "Battle of Kiev \(1941\)") was
overwhelmingly successful, resulting in encirclement and elimination of four
Soviet armies, and made possible further [advance into
Crimea](/wiki/Crimean_Campaign "Crimean Campaign") and industrially developed
Eastern Ukraine (the [First Battle of Kharkov](/wiki/First_Battle_of_Kharkov
"First Battle of Kharkov")).[132]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/RIAN_archive_2153_After_bombing.jpg/220px-
RIAN_archive_2153_After_bombing.jpg)](/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_2153_After_bombing.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_2153_After_bombing.jpg "Enlarge")

Soviet civilians in [Leningrad](/wiki/Leningrad "Leningrad") leaving destroyed
houses, after a German bombardment of the city; [Battle of
Leningrad](/wiki/Battle_of_Leningrad "Battle of Leningrad"), 10 December 1942

The diversion of three quarters of the Axis troops and the majority of their
air forces from France and the central Mediterranean to the [Eastern
Front](/wiki/Eastern_Front_\(World_War_II\) "Eastern Front \(World War
II\)")[133] prompted Britain to reconsider its [grand
strategy](/wiki/Grand_strategy "Grand strategy").[134][_[page
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] In July,
the UK and the Soviet Union formed a [military alliance against
Germany](/wiki/Anglo-Soviet_Agreement "Anglo-Soviet Agreement")[135] The
British and Soviets [invaded neutral Iran](/wiki/Anglo-Soviet_invasion_of_Iran
"Anglo-Soviet invasion of Iran") to secure the [Persian
Corridor](/wiki/Persian_Corridor "Persian Corridor") and Iran's [oil
fields](/wiki/Oil_field "Oil field").[136] In August, the United Kingdom and
the United States jointly issued the [Atlantic Charter](/wiki/Atlantic_Charter
"Atlantic Charter").[137]

By October Axis [operational objectives](/wiki/Operational_objective
"Operational objective") in Ukraine and the Baltic region were achieved, with
only the sieges of [Leningrad](/wiki/Siege_of_Leningrad "Siege of
Leningrad")[138][_[page needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources
"Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] and
[Sevastopol](/wiki/Siege_of_Sevastopol_\(1941%E2%80%9342\) "Siege of
Sevastopol \(1941–42\)") continuing.[139] A major [offensive against
Moscow](/wiki/Battle_of_Moscow "Battle of Moscow") was renewed; after two
months of fierce battles in increasingly harsh weather the German army almost
reached the outer suburbs of Moscow, where the exhausted troops[140] were
forced to suspend their offensive.[141] Large territorial gains were made by
Axis forces, but their campaign had failed to achieve its main objectives: two
key cities remained in Soviet hands, the Soviet [capability to
resist](/wiki/Military_capability "Military capability") was not broken, and
the Soviet Union retained a considerable part of its military potential. The
_blitzkrieg_ [phase](/wiki/Phase_\(combat\) "Phase \(combat\)") of the war in
Europe had ended.[142][_[page needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources
"Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]

By early December, freshly mobilised [reserves](/wiki/Military_reserve_force
"Military reserve force")[143][_[page needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources
"Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] allowed the Soviets to achieve numerical parity
with Axis troops.[144] This, as well as [intelligence
data](/wiki/Richard_Sorge#Wartime_intelligence_supplied_by_the_Sorge_Ring
"Richard Sorge") which established that a minimal number of Soviet troops in
the East would be sufficient to deter any attack by the Japanese [Kwantung
Army](/wiki/Kwantung_Army "Kwantung Army"),[145][_[page
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_] allowed
the Soviets to begin a [massive counter-
offensive](/wiki/Soviet_Offensive_\(1941%E2%80%931942\) "Soviet Offensive
\(1941–1942\)") that started on 5 December all along the front and pushed
German troops 100–250 kilometres (62–155 mi) west.[146]

### War breaks out in the Pacific (1941)

Main article: [Pacific War](/wiki/Pacific_War "Pacific War")

In 1939, the United States had renounced its trade treaty with Japan; and,
beginning with an [aviation gasoline](/wiki/Aviation_gasoline "Aviation
gasoline") ban in July 1940, Japan became subject to increasing economic
pressure.[101] During this time, Japan launched its [first attack against
Changsha](/wiki/Battle_of_Changsha_\(1939\) "Battle of Changsha \(1939\)"), a
strategically important Chinese city, but was repulsed by late September.[147]
Despite [several offensives](/wiki/1939%E2%80%9340_Winter_Offensive "1939–40
Winter Offensive") by both sides, the war between China and Japan was
stalemated by 1940. To increase pressure on China by blocking supply routes,
and to better position Japanese forces in the event of a war with the Western
powers, Japan invaded and [occupied northern
Indochina](/wiki/Japanese_invasion_of_French_Indochina "Japanese invasion of
French Indochina").[148] Afterwards, the United States
[embargoed](/wiki/Embargo "Embargo") iron, steel and mechanical parts against
Japan.[149] Other sanctions soon followed.

Chinese nationalist forces launched a large-scale [counter-
offensive](/wiki/1939%E2%80%9340_Winter_Offensive "1939–40 Winter Offensive")
in early 1940. In August, [Chinese communists](/wiki/Communist_Party_of_China
"Communist Party of China") launched an [offensive in Central
China](/wiki/Hundred_Regiments_Offensive "Hundred Regiments Offensive"); in
retaliation, Japan instituted [harsh measures](/wiki/Three_Alls_Policy "Three
Alls Policy") in occupied areas to reduce human and material resources for the
communists.[150] Continued antipathy between Chinese communist and nationalist
forces [culminated in armed clashes in January
1941](/wiki/New_Fourth_Army_incident "New Fourth Army incident"), effectively
ending their co-operation.[151] In March, the Japanese 11th army attacked the
headquarters of the Chinese 19th army but was repulsed during [Battle of
Shanggao](/wiki/Battle_of_Shanggao "Battle of Shanggao").[152] In September,
Japan attempted to [take the city of
Changsha](/wiki/Battle_of_Changsha_\(1941\) "Battle of Changsha \(1941\)")
again and clashed with Chinese nationalist forces.[153]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Carrier_shokaku.jpg/220px-
Carrier_shokaku.jpg)](/wiki/File:Carrier_shokaku.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Carrier_shokaku.jpg "Enlarge")

[Mitsubishi A6M2](/wiki/Mitsubishi_A6M2 "Mitsubishi A6M2") "Zero" fighters on
the [Imperial Japanese Navy](/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Navy "Imperial Japanese
Navy") aircraft carrier
[_Shōkaku_](/wiki/Japanese_aircraft_carrier_Sh%C5%8Dkaku "Japanese aircraft
carrier Shōkaku"), just before the attack on [Pearl
Harbor](/wiki/Naval_Station_Pearl_Harbor "Naval Station Pearl Harbor")

German successes in Europe encouraged Japan to increase pressure on European
governments in [Southeast Asia](/wiki/Southeast_Asia "Southeast Asia"). The
Dutch government agreed to provide Japan some oil supplies from the [Dutch
East Indies](/wiki/Dutch_East_Indies "Dutch East Indies"), but negotiations
for additional access to their resources ended in failure in June 1941.[154]
In July 1941 Japan sent troops to southern Indochina, thus threatening British
and Dutch possessions in the Far East. The United States, United Kingdom and
other Western governments reacted to this move with a freeze on Japanese
assets and a total oil embargo.[155][156] At the same time, Japan was
[planning an invasion of the Soviet Far East](/wiki/Kantokuen "Kantokuen"),
intending to capitalize off the German invasion in the west, but abandoned the
operation after the sanctions.[157]

Since early 1941 the United States and Japan had been engaged in negotiations
in an attempt to improve their strained relations and end the war in China.
During these negotiations Japan advanced a number of proposals which were
dismissed by the Americans as inadequate.[158] At the same time the US,
Britain, and the Netherlands engaged in secret discussions for the joint
defence of their territories, in the event of a Japanese attack against any of
them.[159] Roosevelt reinforced [the Philippines (an American protectorate
scheduled for independence in 1946)](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_the_Philippines
"Commonwealth of the Philippines") and warned Japan that the US would react to
Japanese attacks against any "neighboring countries".[159]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/The_USS_Arizona_%28BB-39%29_burning_after_the_Japanese_attack_on_Pearl_Harbor_-
_NARA_195617_-_Edit.jpg/220px-
The_USS_Arizona_%28BB-39%29_burning_after_the_Japanese_attack_on_Pearl_Harbor_-
_NARA_195617_-_Edit.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_USS_Arizona_\(BB-39\)_burning_after_the_Japanese_attack_on_Pearl_Harbor_-
_NARA_195617_-_Edit.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_USS_Arizona_\(BB-39\)_burning_after_the_Japanese_attack_on_Pearl_Harbor_-
_NARA_195617_-_Edit.jpg "Enlarge")

[USS  _Arizona_](/wiki/USS_Arizona_\(BB-39\) "USS Arizona \(BB-39\)") during
the Japanese surprise air attack on the [American pacific
fleet](/wiki/United_States_Pacific_Fleet "United States Pacific Fleet"), 7
December 1941

Frustrated at the lack of progress and feeling the pinch of the American-
British-Dutch sanctions, Japan prepared for war. On 20 November a new
government under Hideki Tojo presented an interim proposal as its final offer.
It called for the end of American aid to China and for the supply of oil and
other resources to Japan. In exchange Japan promised not to launch any attacks
in Southeast Asia and to withdraw its forces from southern Indochina.[158] The
American counter-proposal of 26 November required that Japan evacuate all of
China without conditions and conclude non-aggression pacts with all Pacific
powers.[160] That meant Japan was essentially forced to choose between
abandoning its ambitions in China, or seizing the natural resources it needed
in the Dutch East Indies by force;[161] the Japanese military did not consider
the former an option, and many officers considered the oil embargo an unspoken
declaration of war.[162]

Japan planned to rapidly seize European colonies in Asia to create a large
defensive perimeter stretching into the Central Pacific; the Japanese would
then be free to exploit the resources of Southeast Asia while exhausting the
over-stretched Allies by fighting a defensive war.[163] To prevent American
intervention while securing the perimeter it was further planned to neutralise
the [United States Pacific Fleet](/wiki/United_States_Pacific_Fleet "United
States Pacific Fleet") and the American military presence in the Philippines
from the outset.[164] On 7 December 1941 (8 December in Asian time zones),
Japan attacked British and American holdings with near-simultaneous
[offensives against Southeast Asia and the Central
Pacific](/wiki/Japanese_expansion_\(1941%E2%80%931942\) "Japanese expansion
\(1941–1942\)").[165] These included an [attack on the American fleet at Pearl
Harbor](/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor "Attack on Pearl Harbor"), [the
Philippines](/wiki/Philippines_Campaign_\(1941%E2%80%9342\) "Philippines
Campaign \(1941–42\)"), [landings in Thailand and
Malaya](/wiki/Malayan_Campaign "Malayan Campaign")[165] and the [battle of
Hong Kong](/wiki/Battle_of_Hong_Kong "Battle of Hong Kong").

These attacks led the [United
States](/wiki/United_States_declaration_of_war_on_Japan "United States
declaration of war on Japan"),
[Britain](/wiki/United_Kingdom_declaration_of_war_on_Japan "United Kingdom
declaration of war on Japan"), China, Australia and several other states to
formally declare war on Japan, whereas the Soviet Union, being heavily
involved in large-scale hostilities with European Axis countries, maintained
its neutrality agreement with Japan.[166] Germany, followed by the other Axis
states, declared war on the United States[167] in solidarity with Japan,
citing as justification the American attacks on German war vessels that had
been ordered by Roosevelt.[125][168]

### Axis advance stalls (1942–43)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Casablanca-
Conference.jpg/220px-Casablanca-Conference.jpg)](/wiki/File:Casablanca-
Conference.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Casablanca-Conference.jpg "Enlarge")

Seated at the [Casablanca Conference](/wiki/Casablanca_Conference "Casablanca
Conference"); US President [Franklin D. Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt
"Franklin D. Roosevelt") and British PM [Winston
Churchill](/wiki/Winston_Churchill "Winston Churchill"), January 1943

On 1 January 1942, the [Allied Big Four](/wiki/Four_Policemen "Four
Policemen")[169]—the Soviet Union, China, Britain and the United States—and 22
smaller or exiled governments issued the [Declaration by United
Nations](/wiki/Declaration_by_United_Nations "Declaration by United Nations"),
thereby affirming the [Atlantic Charter](/wiki/Atlantic_Charter "Atlantic
Charter"),[170] and agreeing to not to sign a [separate
peace](/wiki/Separate_peace "Separate peace") with the Axis powers.
