During 1942, Allied officials debated on the appropriate [grand
strategy](/wiki/Grand_strategy "Grand strategy") to pursue. All agreed that
[defeating Germany](/wiki/Europe_first "Europe first") was the primary
objective. The Americans favoured a straightforward, [large-scale
attack](/wiki/Operation_Sledgehammer "Operation Sledgehammer") on Germany
through France. The Soviets were also demanding a second front. The British,
on the other hand, argued that military operations should target peripheral
areas to wear out German strength, leading to increasing demoralisation, and
bolster resistance forces. Germany itself would be subject to a heavy bombing
campaign. An offensive against Germany would then be launched primarily by
Allied armour without using large-scale armies.[171] Eventually, the British
persuaded the Americans that a landing in France was infeasible in 1942 and
they should instead focus on driving the Axis out of North Africa.[172]

At the [Casablanca Conference](/wiki/Casablanca_Conference "Casablanca
Conference") in early 1943, the Allies reiterated the statements issued in the
1942 Declaration by the United Nations, and demanded the [unconditional
surrender](/wiki/Unconditional_surrender "Unconditional surrender") of their
enemies. The British and Americans agreed to continue to press the initiative
in the Mediterranean by invading Sicily to fully secure the Mediterranean
supply routes.[173] Although the British argued for further operations in the
Balkans to bring Turkey into the war, in May 1943, the Americans extracted a
British commitment to limit Allied operations in the Mediterranean to an
invasion of the Italian mainland and to invade France in 1944.[174]

#### Pacific (1942–43)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Second_world_war_asia_1937-1942_map_en6.png/350px-
Second_world_war_asia_1937-1942_map_en6.png)](/wiki/File:Second_world_war_asia_1937-1942_map_en6.png)

[](/wiki/File:Second_world_war_asia_1937-1942_map_en6.png "Enlarge")

Map of Japanese military advances, until mid-1942

By the end of April 1942, Japan and its ally Thailand had almost fully
conquered [Burma](/wiki/Japanese_conquest_of_Burma "Japanese conquest of
Burma"), [Malaya](/wiki/Battle_of_Malaya "Battle of Malaya"), [the Dutch East
Indies](/wiki/Dutch_East_Indies_campaign "Dutch East Indies campaign"),
[Singapore](/wiki/Battle_of_Singapore "Battle of Singapore"), and
[Rabaul](/wiki/Rabaul "Rabaul"), inflicting severe losses on Allied troops and
taking a large number of prisoners.[175] Despite stubborn
[resistance](/wiki/Philippines_Campaign_\(1941%E2%80%9342\) "Philippines
Campaign \(1941–42\)") by Filipino and US forces, the [Philippine
Commonwealth](/wiki/Philippine_Commonwealth "Philippine Commonwealth") was
eventually captured in May 1942, forcing its government into exile.[176] On 16
April, in Burma, 7,000 British soldiers were encircled by the Japanese 33rd
Division during the [Battle of Yenangyaung](/wiki/Battle_of_Yenangyaung
"Battle of Yenangyaung") and rescued by the Chinese 38th Division.[177]
Japanese forces also achieved naval victories in the [South China
Sea](/wiki/Sinking_of_Prince_of_Wales_and_Repulse "Sinking of Prince of Wales
and Repulse"), [Java Sea](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Java_Sea "Battle of the Java
Sea") and [Indian Ocean](/wiki/Indian_Ocean_raid_\(1942\) "Indian Ocean raid
\(1942\)"),[178] and [bombed the Allied naval base](/wiki/Bombing_of_Darwin
"Bombing of Darwin") at [Darwin](/wiki/Darwin,_Northern_Territory "Darwin,
Northern Territory"), Australia. In January 1942, the only Allied success
against Japan was a Chinese [victory at
Changsha](/wiki/Battle_of_Changsha_\(1942\) "Battle of Changsha
\(1942\)").[179] These easy victories over unprepared US and European
opponents left Japan overconfident, as well as overextended.[180]

In early May 1942, Japan initiated operations to [capture Port
Moresby](/wiki/Operation_Mo "Operation Mo") by [amphibious
assault](/wiki/Amphibious_assault "Amphibious assault") and thus sever
communications and supply lines between the United States and Australia. The
planned invasion was thwarted when an Allied task force, centred on two
American fleet carriers, fought Japanese naval forces to a draw in the [Battle
of the Coral Sea](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Coral_Sea "Battle of the Coral
Sea").[181] Japan's next plan, motivated by the earlier [Doolittle
Raid](/wiki/Doolittle_Raid "Doolittle Raid"), was to seize [Midway
Atoll](/wiki/Midway_Atoll "Midway Atoll") and lure American carriers into
battle to be eliminated; as a diversion, Japan would also send forces to
[occupy the Aleutian Islands](/wiki/Aleutian_Islands_Campaign "Aleutian
Islands Campaign") in Alaska.[182] In mid-May, Japan started the [Zhejiang-
Jiangxi Campaign](/wiki/Zhejiang-Jiangxi_Campaign "Zhejiang-Jiangxi Campaign")
in China, with the goal of inflicting retribution on the Chinese who aided the
surviving American airmen in the Doolittle Raid by destroying air bases and
fighting against the Chinese 23rd and 32nd Army Groups.[183][184] In early
June, Japan put its operations into action but the Americans, having broken
[Japanese naval codes](/wiki/Japanese_naval_codes "Japanese naval codes") in
late May, were fully aware of plans and order of battle, and used this
knowledge to achieve a decisive [victory at Midway](/wiki/Battle_of_Midway
"Battle of Midway") over the [Imperial Japanese
Navy](/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Navy "Imperial Japanese Navy").[185]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Marines_rest_in_the_field_on_Guadalcanal.jpg/220px-
Marines_rest_in_the_field_on_Guadalcanal.jpg)](/wiki/File:Marines_rest_in_the_field_on_Guadalcanal.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Marines_rest_in_the_field_on_Guadalcanal.jpg "Enlarge")

[US Marines](/wiki/United_States_Marine_Corps "United States Marine Corps")
during the [Guadalcanal Campaign](/wiki/Guadalcanal_Campaign "Guadalcanal
Campaign"), in the [Pacific
theatre](/wiki/Pacific_Ocean_theater_of_World_War_II "Pacific Ocean theater of
World War II"), 1942

With its capacity for aggressive action greatly diminished as a result of the
Midway battle, Japan chose to focus on a belated attempt to capture [Port
Moresby](/wiki/Port_Moresby "Port Moresby") by an [overland
campaign](/wiki/Kokoda_Track_campaign "Kokoda Track campaign") in the
[Territory of Papua](/wiki/Territory_of_Papua "Territory of Papua").[186] The
Americans planned a counter-attack against Japanese positions in the southern
[Solomon Islands](/wiki/Solomon_Islands "Solomon Islands"), primarily
[Guadalcanal](/wiki/Guadalcanal "Guadalcanal"), as a first step towards
capturing [Rabaul](/wiki/Rabaul "Rabaul"), the main Japanese base in Southeast
Asia.[187]

Both plans started in July, but by mid-September, [the Battle for
Guadalcanal](/wiki/Guadalcanal_Campaign "Guadalcanal Campaign") took priority
for the Japanese, and troops in New Guinea were ordered to withdraw from the
Port Moresby area to the [northern part of the island](/wiki/Oro_Province "Oro
Province"), where they faced Australian and United States troops in the
[Battle of Buna-Gona](/wiki/Battle_of_Buna-Gona "Battle of Buna-Gona").[188]
Guadalcanal soon became a focal point for both sides with heavy commitments of
troops and ships in the battle for Guadalcanal. By the start of 1943, the
Japanese were defeated on the island and [withdrew their
troops](/wiki/Operation_Ke "Operation Ke").[189] In Burma, Commonwealth forces
mounted two operations. The first, [an offensive into the Arakan
region](/wiki/Arakan_Campaign_1942%E2%80%9343 "Arakan Campaign 1942–43") in
late 1942, went disastrously, forcing a retreat back to India by May
1943.[190] The second was the [insertion of irregular
forces](/wiki/Operation_Longcloth "Operation Longcloth") behind Japanese
front-lines in February which, by the end of April, had achieved mixed
results.[191]

#### Eastern Front (1942–43)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/RIAN_archive_44732_Soviet_soldiers_attack_house.jpg/300px-
RIAN_archive_44732_Soviet_soldiers_attack_house.jpg)](/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_44732_Soviet_soldiers_attack_house.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_44732_Soviet_soldiers_attack_house.jpg "Enlarge")

[Red Army](/wiki/Red_Army "Red Army") soldiers on the counterattack, during
the [Battle of Stalingrad](/wiki/Battle_of_Stalingrad "Battle of Stalingrad"),
February 1943

Despite considerable losses, in early 1942 Germany and its allies stopped a
major Soviet offensive in central and southern Russia, keeping most
territorial gains they had achieved during the previous year.[192] In May the
Germans defeated Soviet offensives in the [Kerch
Peninsula](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Kerch_Peninsula "Battle of the Kerch
Peninsula") and at [Kharkov](/wiki/Second_Battle_of_Kharkov "Second Battle of
Kharkov"),[193] and then launched their main [summer
offensive](/wiki/Case_Blue "Case Blue") against southern Russia in June 1942,
to seize the [oil fields of the Caucasus](/wiki/Baku_Oil_Fields "Baku Oil
Fields") and occupy [Kuban](/wiki/Kuban "Kuban") [steppe](/wiki/Steppe
"Steppe"), while maintaining positions on the northern and central areas of
the front. The Germans split [Army Group South](/wiki/Army_Group_South "Army
Group South") into two groups: [Army Group A](/wiki/Army_Group_A "Army Group
A") advanced to the lower [Don River](/wiki/Don_River_\(Russia\) "Don River
\(Russia\)") and struck south-east to the Caucasus, while [Army Group
B](/wiki/Army_Group_B "Army Group B") headed towards the [Volga
River](/wiki/Volga_River "Volga River"). The Soviets decided to make their
stand at Stalingrad on the Volga.[194]

By mid-November, the Germans had [nearly taken
Stalingrad](/wiki/Battle_of_Stalingrad "Battle of Stalingrad") in bitter
[street fighting](/wiki/Urban_warfare "Urban warfare") when the Soviets began
their second winter counter-offensive, starting with an [encirclement of
German forces at Stalingrad](/wiki/Operation_Uranus "Operation Uranus")[195]
and an assault on the [Rzhev salient near Moscow](/wiki/Operation_Mars
"Operation Mars"), though the latter failed disastrously.[196] By early
February 1943, the German Army had taken tremendous losses; German troops at
Stalingrad had been forced to surrender,[197] and the front-line had been
pushed back beyond its position before the summer offensive. In mid-February,
after the Soviet push had tapered off, the Germans launched another [attack on
Kharkov](/wiki/Third_Battle_of_Kharkov "Third Battle of Kharkov"), creating a
[salient](/wiki/Salients,_re-entrants_and_pockets "Salients, re-entrants and
pockets") in their front line around the Russian city of [Kursk](/wiki/Kursk
"Kursk").[198]

#### Western Europe/Atlantic & Mediterranean (1942–43)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/8th_AF_Bombing_Marienburg.JPEG/220px-8th_AF_Bombing_Marienburg.JPEG)](/wiki/File:8th_AF_Bombing_Marienburg.JPEG)

[](/wiki/File:8th_AF_Bombing_Marienburg.JPEG "Enlarge")

American [8th Air Force](/wiki/8th_Air_Force "8th Air Force") [Boeing B-17
Flying Fortress](/wiki/Boeing_B-17_Flying_Fortress "Boeing B-17 Flying
Fortress") bombing raid on the Focke-Wulf factory in Germany, 9 October 1943

Exploiting poor American naval command decisions, [the German navy ravaged
Allied shipping off the American Atlantic coast](/wiki/Second_Happy_Time
"Second Happy Time").[199] By November 1941, Commonwealth forces had launched
a counter-offensive, [Operation Crusader](/wiki/Operation_Crusader "Operation
Crusader"), in North Africa, and reclaimed all the gains the Germans and
Italians had made.[200] In North Africa, the Germans launched an offensive in
January, pushing the British back to positions at the [Gazala
Line](/wiki/Gazala_Line "Gazala Line") by early February,[201] followed by a
temporary lull in combat which Germany used to prepare for their upcoming
offensives.[202] Concerns the Japanese might use bases in Vichy-held
[Madagascar](/wiki/Madagascar "Madagascar") caused the British to [invade the
island](/wiki/Battle_of_Madagascar "Battle of Madagascar") in early May
1942.[203] An Axis [offensive in Libya](/wiki/Battle_of_Gazala "Battle of
Gazala") forced an Allied retreat deep inside Egypt until Axis forces were
[stopped at El Alamein](/wiki/First_Battle_of_El_Alamein "First Battle of El
Alamein").[204] On the Continent, raids of Allied [commandos](/wiki/Commando
"Commando") on strategic targets, culminating in the disastrous [Dieppe
Raid](/wiki/Dieppe_Raid "Dieppe Raid"),[205] demonstrated the Western Allies'
inability to launch an invasion of continental Europe without much better
preparation, equipment, and operational security.[206][_[page
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]

In August 1942, the Allies succeeded in repelling a [second attack against El
Alamein](/wiki/Battle_of_Alam_el_Halfa "Battle of Alam el Halfa")[207] and, at
a high cost, managed to [deliver desperately needed supplies to the besieged
Malta](/wiki/Operation_Pedestal "Operation Pedestal").[208] A few months
later, the Allies [commenced an attack of their
own](/wiki/Second_Battle_of_El_Alamein "Second Battle of El Alamein") in
Egypt, dislodging the Axis forces and beginning a drive west across
Libya.[209] This attack was followed up shortly after by [Anglo-American
landings in French North Africa](/wiki/Operation_Torch "Operation Torch"),
which resulted in the region joining the Allies.[210] Hitler responded to the
French colony's defection by ordering the [occupation of Vichy
France](/wiki/Case_Anton "Case Anton");[210] although Vichy forces did not
resist this violation of the armistice, they managed to [scuttle their
fleet](/wiki/Scuttling_of_the_French_fleet_in_Toulon "Scuttling of the French
fleet in Toulon") to prevent its capture by German forces.[210][211] The now
pincered Axis forces in Africa withdrew into [Tunisia](/wiki/Tunisia
"Tunisia"), which was [conquered by the Allies](/wiki/Tunisian_Campaign
"Tunisian Campaign") in May 1943.[210][212]

In early 1943 the British and Americans began the [Combined Bomber
Offensive](/wiki/Combined_Bomber_Offensive "Combined Bomber Offensive"), a
strategic bombing campaign against Germany. The goals were to disrupt the
German war economy, reduce German morale, and "[de-house](/wiki/De-housing
"De-housing")" the civilian population.[213]

### Allies gain momentum (1943–44)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/SBD_VB-16_over_USS_Washington_1943.jpg/220px-
SBD_VB-16_over_USS_Washington_1943.jpg)](/wiki/File:SBD_VB-16_over_USS_Washington_1943.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:SBD_VB-16_over_USS_Washington_1943.jpg "Enlarge")

US Navy [SBD-5](/wiki/Douglas_SBD_Dauntless "Douglas SBD Dauntless") [scout
plane](/wiki/Scout_plane "Scout plane") flies patrol over [USS
_Washington_](/wiki/USS_Washington_\(BB-56\) "USS Washington \(BB-56\)") and
[USS  _Lexington_](/wiki/USS_Lexington_\(CV-2\) "USS Lexington \(CV-2\)")
during the Gilbert and Marshall Islands campaign, 1943

After the Guadalcanal Campaign, the Allies initiated several operations
against Japan in the Pacific. In May 1943, Canadian and U.S. forces were sent
to [eliminate Japanese forces from the
Aleutians](/wiki/Aleutian_Islands_Campaign#Allied_response "Aleutian Islands
Campaign").[214] Soon after, the U.S., with support from Australian and New
Zealand forces, began major operations to [isolate Rabaul by capturing
surrounding islands](/wiki/Operation_Cartwheel "Operation Cartwheel"), and
[breach the Japanese Central Pacific perimeter at the Gilbert and Marshall
Islands](/wiki/Gilbert_and_Marshall_Islands_campaign "Gilbert and Marshall
Islands campaign").[215] By the end of March 1944, the Allies had completed
both of these objectives, and had also [neutralised the major Japanese base at
Truk](/wiki/Operation_Hailstone "Operation Hailstone") in the [Caroline
Islands](/wiki/Caroline_Islands "Caroline Islands"). In April, the Allies
launched an operation to [retake Western New
Guinea](/wiki/Western_New_Guinea_campaign "Western New Guinea campaign").[216]
In the Soviet Union, both the Germans and the Soviets spent the spring and
early summer of 1943 preparing for large offensives in central Russia. On 4
July 1943, Germany [attacked Soviet forces around the Kursk
Bulge](/wiki/Battle_of_Kursk "Battle of Kursk"). Within a week, German forces
had exhausted themselves against the Soviets' deeply echeloned and well-
constructed defences[217] and, for the first time in the war, Hitler cancelled
the operation before it had achieved tactical or operational success.[218]
This decision was partially affected by the Western Allies' [invasion of
Sicily](/wiki/Allied_invasion_of_Sicily "Allied invasion of Sicily") launched
on 9 July which, combined with previous Italian failures, resulted in the
ousting and arrest of Mussolini later that month.[219] Also, in July 1943 the
British [firebombed Hamburg](/wiki/Bombing_of_Hamburg_in_World_War_II "Bombing
of Hamburg in World War II") killing over 40,000 people.[220]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Kursk_Soviet_machineguns.JPG/220px-
Kursk_Soviet_machineguns.JPG)](/wiki/File:Kursk_Soviet_machineguns.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Kursk_Soviet_machineguns.JPG "Enlarge")

[Red Army](/wiki/Red_Army "Red Army") troops, in a counter-offensive on German
positions, at the [Battle of Kursk](/wiki/Battle_of_Kursk "Battle of Kursk"),
1943

On 12 July 1943, the Soviets launched their own [counter-
offensives](/wiki/Operation_Kutuzov "Operation Kutuzov"), thereby dispelling
any chance of German victory or even stalemate in the east. The Soviet victory
at Kursk marked the end of German superiority,[221] giving the Soviet Union
the initiative on the Eastern Front.[222][223] The Germans tried to stabilise
their eastern front along the hastily fortified [Panther–Wotan
line](/wiki/Panther%E2%80%93Wotan_line "Panther–Wotan line"), but the Soviets
broke through it at [Smolensk](/wiki/Battle_of_Smolensk_\(1943\) "Battle of
Smolensk \(1943\)") and by the [Lower Dnieper
Offensives](/wiki/Lower_Dnieper_Offensive "Lower Dnieper Offensive").[224]

On 3 September 1943, the Western Allies [invaded the Italian
mainland](/wiki/Allied_invasion_of_Italy "Allied invasion of Italy"),
following [Italy's armistice with the Allies](/wiki/Armistice_of_Cassibile
"Armistice of Cassibile").[225] Germany with the help of fascists responded by
disarming Italian forces that were in many places without superior orders,
seizing military control of Italian areas,[226] and creating a series of
defensive lines.[227] German special forces then [rescued
Mussolini](/wiki/Gran_Sasso_raid "Gran Sasso raid"), who then soon established
a new client state in German-occupied Italy named the [Italian Social
Republic](/wiki/Italian_Social_Republic "Italian Social Republic"),[228]
causing an [Italian civil war](/wiki/Italian_Civil_War "Italian Civil War").
The Western Allies fought through several lines until reaching the [main
German defensive line](/wiki/Winter_Line "Winter Line") in mid-November.[229]

[![Three men, Chiang Kai-shek, Roosevelt and Churchill, sitting together elbow
to
elbow](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Cairo_conference.jpg/220px-
Cairo_conference.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cairo_conference.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cairo_conference.jpg "Enlarge")

The Allied leaders of the [Asian and Pacific Theatre](/wiki/Pacific_War
"Pacific War"): Generalissimo [Chiang Kai-shek](/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek "Chiang
Kai-shek"), [Franklin D. Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D.
Roosevelt"), and [Winston Churchill](/wiki/Winston_Churchill "Winston
Churchill") meeting at the [Cairo Conference](/wiki/Cairo_Conference_\(1943\)
"Cairo Conference \(1943\)"), 25 November 1943

German operations in the Atlantic also suffered. By [May 1943, as Allied
counter-measures became increasingly effective](/wiki/Black_May_\(1943\)
"Black May \(1943\)"), the resulting sizeable German submarine losses forced a
temporary halt of the German Atlantic naval campaign.[230] In November 1943,
[Franklin D. Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt")
and Winston Churchill met with [Chiang Kai-shek](/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek "Chiang
Kai-shek") [in Cairo](/wiki/Cairo_Conference "Cairo Conference") and then with
Joseph Stalin [in Tehran](/wiki/Tehran_Conference "Tehran Conference").[231]
The former conference determined the post-war return of Japanese
territory[232] and the military planning for the [Burma
Campaign](/wiki/Burma_Campaign "Burma Campaign"),[233] while the latter
included agreement that the Western Allies would invade Europe in 1944 and
that the Soviet Union would declare war on Japan within three months of
Germany's defeat.[234]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/The_Battle_of_Cassino%2C_January-
may_1944_C4363.jpg/220px-The_Battle_of_Cassino%2C_January-
may_1944_C4363.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Battle_of_Cassino,_January-
may_1944_C4363.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_Battle_of_Cassino,_January-may_1944_C4363.jpg "Enlarge")

Ruins of the [Benedictine](/wiki/Monte_Cassino "Monte Cassino") monastery,
during the [Battle of Monte Cassino](/wiki/Battle_of_Monte_Cassino "Battle of
Monte Cassino"); [Italian Campaign](/wiki/Italian_Campaign_\(World_War_II\)
"Italian Campaign \(World War II\)"), May 1944

From November 1943, during the seven-week [Battle of
Changde](/wiki/Battle_of_Changde "Battle of Changde"), the Chinese forced
Japan to fight a costly war of attrition, while awaiting Allied
relief.[235][236][237] In January 1944, the Allies launched a [series of
attacks in Italy against the line at Monte
Cassino](/wiki/Battle_of_Monte_Cassino "Battle of Monte Cassino") and tried to
outflank it with [landings at Anzio](/wiki/Operation_Shingle "Operation
Shingle").[238] By the end of January, a major [Soviet](/wiki/Leningrad_Front
"Leningrad Front") [offensive expelled German
forces](/wiki/Siege_of_Leningrad#Soviet_relief_of_the_siege "Siege of
Leningrad") from the [Leningrad region](/wiki/Leningrad_Oblast "Leningrad
Oblast"),[239] ending the longest and [most lethal siege in
history](/wiki/List_of_battles_by_casualties#Sieges_and_urban_combat "List of
battles by casualties").

The [following Soviet offensive](/wiki/Leningrad%E2%80%93Novgorod_Offensive
"Leningrad–Novgorod Offensive") was [halted on the pre-war Estonian
border](/wiki/Battle_of_Narva_\(1944\) "Battle of Narva \(1944\)") by the
German [Army Group North](/wiki/Army_Group_North "Army Group North") aided by
[Estonians](/wiki/Occupation_of_Estonia_by_Nazi_Germany#Estonians_in_German_Military_Units_in_1941.E2.80.931944
"Occupation of Estonia by Nazi Germany") hoping to [re-establish national
independence](/wiki/Estonian_Government_in_Exile#Failure_to_reestablish_independence
"Estonian Government in Exile"). This delay slowed subsequent Soviet
operations in the [Baltic Sea](/wiki/Baltic_Sea "Baltic Sea") region.[240] By
late May 1944, the Soviets had [liberated Crimea](/wiki/Crimean_Offensive
"Crimean Offensive"), largely expelled Axis forces from Ukraine, and made
[incursions into Romania](/wiki/First_Jassy-Kishinev_Offensive "First Jassy-
Kishinev Offensive"), which were repulsed by the Axis troops.[241] The Allied
offensives in Italy had succeeded and, at the expense of allowing several
German divisions to retreat, on 4 June, Rome was captured.[242]

The Allies had mixed success in mainland Asia. In March 1944, the Japanese
launched the first of two invasions, [an operation against British positions
in Assam, India](/wiki/Operation_U-Go "Operation U-Go"),[243] and soon
besieged Commonwealth positions at [Imphal](/wiki/Battle_of_Imphal "Battle of
Imphal") and [Kohima](/wiki/Battle_of_Kohima "Battle of Kohima").[244] In May
1944, British forces mounted a counter-offensive that drove Japanese troops
back to Burma,[244] and Chinese forces that had [invaded northern
Burma](/wiki/Battle_of_Northern_Burma_and_Western_Yunnan "Battle of Northern
Burma and Western Yunnan") in late 1943 [besieged Japanese
troops](/wiki/Siege_of_Myitkyina "Siege of Myitkyina") in
[Myitkyina](/wiki/Myitkyina "Myitkyina").[245] The [second Japanese
invasion](/wiki/Operation_Ichi-Go "Operation Ichi-Go") of China aimed to
destroy China's main fighting forces, secure railways between Japanese-held
territory and capture Allied airfields.[246] By June, the Japanese had
conquered the province of [Henan](/wiki/Henan "Henan") and begun a [new attack
on Changsha](/wiki/Battle_of_Changsha_\(1944\) "Battle of Changsha \(1944\)")
in the [Hunan](/wiki/Hunan "Hunan") province.[247]

### Allies close in (1944)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Approaching_Omaha.jpg/220px-
Approaching_Omaha.jpg)](/wiki/File:Approaching_Omaha.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Approaching_Omaha.jpg "Enlarge")

American troops approaching [Omaha Beach](/wiki/Omaha_Beach "Omaha Beach"),
during the [Invasion of Normandy](/wiki/Invasion_of_Normandy "Invasion of
Normandy") on [D-Day](/wiki/D-Day "D-Day"), 6 June 1944

On 6 June 1944 (known as [D-Day](/wiki/Normandy_landings "Normandy
landings")), after three years of Soviet pressure,[248] the Western Allies
[invaded northern France](/wiki/Invasion_of_Normandy "Invasion of Normandy").
After reassigning several Allied divisions from Italy, they also [attacked
southern France](/wiki/Operation_Dragoon "Operation Dragoon").[249] These
landings were successful, and led to the defeat of the [German Army
units](/wiki/Falaise_Pocket "Falaise Pocket") in France. Paris was
[liberated](/wiki/Liberation_of_Paris "Liberation of Paris") by the [local
resistance](/wiki/French_Resistance "French Resistance") assisted by the [Free
French Forces](/wiki/Free_French_Forces "Free French Forces"), both led by
General [Charles de Gaulle](/wiki/Charles_de_Gaulle "Charles de Gaulle"), on
25 August[250] and the Western Allies continued to [push back German
forces](/wiki/Allied_advance_from_Paris_to_the_Rhine "Allied advance from
Paris to the Rhine") in western Europe during the latter part of the year. An
attempt to advance into northern Germany spearheaded by [a major airborne
operation](/wiki/Operation_Market_Garden "Operation Market Garden") in the
Netherlands failed.[251] After that, the Western Allies slowly pushed into
Germany, but [failed to cross the Ruhr river](/wiki/Operation_Queen "Operation
Queen") in a large offensive. In Italy, Allied advance also slowed due to the
[last major German defensive line](/wiki/Gothic_Line "Gothic Line").[252]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-97906%2C_Warschauer_Aufstand%2C_Stra%C3%9Fenkampf.jpg/220px-
Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-97906%2C_Warschauer_Aufstand%2C_Stra%C3%9Fenkampf.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-97906,_Warschauer_Aufstand,_Stra%C3%9Fenkampf.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-97906,_Warschauer_Aufstand,_Stra%C3%9Fenkampf.jpg
"Enlarge")

German [SS](/wiki/Schutzstaffel "Schutzstaffel") soldiers from the
[Dirlewanger Brigade](/wiki/Dirlewanger_Brigade "Dirlewanger Brigade"), tasked
with suppressing the [Warsaw Uprising](/wiki/Warsaw_Uprising "Warsaw
Uprising") against Nazi occupation, August 1944

On 22 June, the Soviets launched a strategic offensive in Belarus ("[Operation
Bagration](/wiki/Operation_Bagration "Operation Bagration")") that destroyed
the German [Army Group Centre](/wiki/Army_Group_Centre "Army Group Centre")
almost completely.[253] Soon after that [another Soviet strategic
offensive](/wiki/Lvov%E2%80%93Sandomierz_Offensive "Lvov–Sandomierz
Offensive") forced German troops from Western Ukraine and Eastern Poland. The
Soviet advance prompted [resistance forces in Poland](/wiki/Armia_Krajowa
"Armia Krajowa") to [initiate several uprisings](/wiki/Operation_Tempest
"Operation Tempest") against the German occupation. However, the largest of
these [in Warsaw](/wiki/Warsaw_Uprising "Warsaw Uprising"), where German
soldiers massacred 200,000 civilians, and a [national
uprising](/wiki/Slovak_National_Uprising "Slovak National Uprising") in
[Slovakia](/wiki/Slovak_Republic_\(1939%E2%80%931945\) "Slovak Republic
\(1939–1945\)"), did not receive Soviet support and were subsequently
suppressed by the Germans.[254] The Red Army's [strategic offensive in eastern
Romania](/wiki/Jassy%E2%80%93Kishinev_Offensive "Jassy–Kishinev Offensive")
cut off and destroyed the [considerable German troops
there](/wiki/Army_Group_South_Ukraine "Army Group South Ukraine") and
triggered [a successful coup d'état in Romania](/wiki/King_Michael%27s_Coup
"King Michael's Coup") and [in
Bulgaria](/wiki/Bulgarian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_of_1944 "Bulgarian coup d'état of
1944"), followed by those countries' shift to the Allied side.[255]

In September 1944, Soviet troops advanced into
[Yugoslavia](/wiki/Democratic_Federal_Yugoslavia "Democratic Federal
Yugoslavia") and forced the rapid withdrawal of German Army Groups
[E](/wiki/Army_Group_E "Army Group E") and [F](/wiki/Army_Group_F "Army Group
F") in [Greece](/wiki/Axis_occupation_of_Greece "Axis occupation of Greece"),
[Albania](/wiki/Albanian_Kingdom_\(1943%E2%80%9344\) "Albanian Kingdom
\(1943–44\)") and Yugoslavia to rescue them from being cut off.[256] By this
point, the Communist-led [Partisans](/wiki/Yugoslav_Partisans "Yugoslav
Partisans") under Marshal [Josip Broz Tito](/wiki/Josip_Broz_Tito "Josip Broz
Tito"), who had led an [increasingly successful guerrilla
campaign](/wiki/World_War_II_in_Yugoslavia "World War II in Yugoslavia")
against the occupation since 1941, controlled much of the territory of
Yugoslavia and engaged in delaying efforts against German forces further
south. In northern [Serbia](/wiki/Serbia_\(1941%E2%80%931944\) "Serbia
\(1941–1944\)"), the [Red Army](/wiki/Red_Army "Red Army"), with limited
support from Bulgarian forces, assisted the Partisans in a joint [liberation
of the capital city of Belgrade](/wiki/Belgrade_Offensive "Belgrade
Offensive") on 20 October. A few days later, the Soviets launched a [massive
assault](/wiki/Budapest_Offensive "Budapest Offensive") against [German-
occupied](/wiki/Operation_Panzerfaust "Operation Panzerfaust") Hungary that
lasted until [the fall of Budapest](/wiki/Battle_of_Budapest "Battle of
Budapest") in February 1945.[257] Unlike impressive Soviet victories in the
Balkans, [bitter Finnish resistance](/wiki/Continuation_War "Continuation
War") to the [Soviet offensive](/wiki/Vyborg%E2%80%93Petrozavodsk_Offensive
"Vyborg–Petrozavodsk Offensive") in the [Karelian
Isthmus](/wiki/Karelian_Isthmus "Karelian Isthmus") denied the Soviets
occupation of Finland and led to a [Soviet-Finnish
armistice](/wiki/Moscow_Armistice "Moscow Armistice") on relatively mild
conditions,[258][259] although Finland was forced to [fight their former
allies](/wiki/Lapland_War "Lapland War").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg/220px-
Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Douglas_MacArthur_lands_Leyte1.jpg "Enlarge")

General [Douglas MacArthur](/wiki/Douglas_MacArthur "Douglas MacArthur") lands
at [Leyte](/wiki/Leyte "Leyte"), during the [Battle of
Leyte](/wiki/Battle_of_Leyte "Battle of Leyte"), 20 October 1944

By the start of July 1944, Commonwealth forces in Southeast Asia had repelled
the Japanese sieges in Assam, pushing the Japanese back to the [Chindwin
River](/wiki/Chindwin_River "Chindwin River")[260] while the Chinese captured
Myitkyina. In September 1944, Chinese force [captured the Mount
Song](/wiki/Battle_of_Mount_Song "Battle of Mount Song") to reopen the [Burma
Road](/wiki/Burma_Road "Burma Road").[261] In China, the Japanese had more
successes, having finally captured Changsha in mid-June and the city of
[Hengyang](/wiki/Defense_of_Hengyang "Defense of Hengyang") by early
August.[262] Soon after, they invaded the province of Guangxi, winning major
engagements against Chinese forces at [Guilin and
Liuzhou](/wiki/Battle_of_Guilin%E2%80%93Liuzhou "Battle of Guilin–Liuzhou") by
the end of November[263] and successfully linking up their forces in China and
Indochina by mid-December.[264]

In the Pacific, US forces continued to press back the Japanese perimeter. In
mid-June 1944, they began their [offensive against the Mariana and Palau
islands](/wiki/Mariana_and_Palau_Islands_campaign "Mariana and Palau Islands
campaign"), and decisively defeated Japanese forces in the [Battle of the
Philippine Sea](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Philippine_Sea "Battle of the Philippine
Sea"). These defeats led to the resignation of the Japanese Prime Minister,
[Hideki Tojo](/wiki/Hideki_Tojo "Hideki Tojo"), and provided the United States
with air bases to launch intensive heavy bomber attacks on the Japanese home
islands. In late October, American forces [invaded the Filipino island of
Leyte](/wiki/Battle_of_Leyte "Battle of Leyte"); soon after, Allied naval
forces scored another large victory in the [Battle of Leyte
Gulf](/wiki/Battle_of_Leyte_Gulf "Battle of Leyte Gulf"), one of the largest
naval battles in history.[265]

### Axis collapse, Allied victory (1944–45)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Yalta_Conference_%28Churchill%2C_Roosevelt%2C_Stalin%29_%28B%26W%29.jpg/220px-
Yalta_Conference_%28Churchill%2C_Roosevelt%2C_Stalin%29_%28B%26W%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yalta_Conference_\(Churchill,_Roosevelt,_Stalin\)_\(B%26W\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Yalta_Conference_\(Churchill,_Roosevelt,_Stalin\)_\(B%26W\).jpg
"Enlarge")

[Yalta Conference](/wiki/Yalta_Conference "Yalta Conference") held in February
1945, with [Winston Churchill](/wiki/Winston_Churchill "Winston Churchill"),
[Franklin D. Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt")
and [Joseph Stalin](/wiki/Joseph_Stalin "Joseph Stalin")

On 16 December 1944, Germany made a last attempt on the Western Front by using
most of its remaining reserves to launch [a massive counter-offensive in the
Ardennes](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Bulge "Battle of the Bulge") and [along the
French–German border](/wiki/Operation_Nordwind "Operation Nordwind") to split
the Western Allies, encircle large portions of Western Allied troops and
capture their primary supply port at [Antwerp](/wiki/Antwerp "Antwerp") to
prompt a political settlement.[266] By January, the offensive had been
repulsed with no strategic objectives fulfilled.[266] In Italy, the Western
Allies remained stalemated at the German defensive line. In mid-January 1945,
the Soviets and Poles attacked in Poland, [pushing from the Vistula to the
Oder](/wiki/Vistula%E2%80%93Oder_Offensive "Vistula–Oder Offensive") river in
Germany, and [overran East Prussia](/wiki/East_Prussian_Offensive "East
Prussian Offensive").[267] On 4 February, Soviet, British and US leaders met
for the [Yalta Conference](/wiki/Yalta_Conference "Yalta Conference"). They
agreed on the occupation of post-war Germany, and on when the Soviet Union
would join the war against Japan.[268]

In February, the Soviets [entered Silesia](/wiki/Silesian_Offensives "Silesian
Offensives") and [Pomerania](/wiki/East_Pomeranian_Offensive "East Pomeranian
Offensive"), while [Western Allies entered western
Germany](/wiki/Western_Allied_invasion_of_Germany "Western Allied invasion of
Germany") and closed to the [Rhine](/wiki/Rhine "Rhine") river. By March, the
Western Allies crossed the Rhine [north](/wiki/Operation_Plunder "Operation
Plunder") and [south](/wiki/Remagen "Remagen") of the [Ruhr](/wiki/Rhine-Ruhr
"Rhine-Ruhr"), [encircling the German Army Group B](/wiki/Ruhr_Pocket "Ruhr
Pocket"),[269] while the Soviets advanced to [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna").
In early April, the Western Allies finally [pushed forward in
Italy](/wiki/Spring_1945_offensive_in_Italy "Spring 1945 offensive in Italy")
and swept across western Germany capturing
[Hamburg](/wiki/Battle_of_Hamburg_\(1945\) "Battle of Hamburg \(1945\)") and
[Nuremberg](/wiki/Battle_of_Nuremberg_\(1945\) "Battle of Nuremberg
\(1945\)"), while Soviet and Polish forces [stormed
Berlin](/wiki/Battle_of_Berlin "Battle of Berlin") in late April. [American
and Soviet forces met at the Elbe river](/wiki/Elbe_Day "Elbe Day") on 25
April. On 30 April 1945, the [Reichstag](/wiki/Reichstag_building "Reichstag
building") was captured, signalling the military defeat of Nazi Germany.[270]

Several changes in leadership occurred during this period. On 12 April,
President Roosevelt died and was succeeded by [Harry S.
Truman](/wiki/Harry_S._Truman "Harry S. Truman"). Benito Mussolini [was
killed](/wiki/Death_of_Benito_Mussolini "Death of Benito Mussolini") by
[Italian partisans](/wiki/Italian_resistance_movement "Italian resistance
movement") on 28 April.[271] Two days later, [Hitler committed
suicide](/wiki/Death_of_Adolf_Hitler "Death of Adolf Hitler"), and was
succeeded by [Grand Admiral](/wiki/Grand_Admiral "Grand Admiral") [Karl
Dönitz](/wiki/Karl_D%C3%B6nitz "Karl Dönitz").[272]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Reichstag_after_the_allied_bombing_of_Berlin.jpg/220px-
Reichstag_after_the_allied_bombing_of_Berlin.jpg)](/wiki/File:Reichstag_after_the_allied_bombing_of_Berlin.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Reichstag_after_the_allied_bombing_of_Berlin.jpg "Enlarge")

The German [Reichstag](/wiki/Reichstag_building "Reichstag building") after
its capture by the Allied forces, 3 June 1945

German forces surrendered in Italy on 29 April. [Total and unconditional
surrender](/wiki/German_Instrument_of_Surrender "German Instrument of
Surrender") was signed [on 7 May](/wiki/Victory_in_Europe_Day "Victory in
Europe Day"), to be effective by the end of [8
May](/wiki/Victory_Day_\(Eastern_Front\) "Victory Day \(Eastern
Front\)").[273] German Army Group Centre [resisted in
Prague](/wiki/Prague_Offensive "Prague Offensive") until 11 May.[274]

In the Pacific theatre, American forces accompanied by the forces of the
[Philippine Commonwealth](/wiki/Philippine_Commonwealth "Philippine
Commonwealth") advanced [in the
Philippines](/wiki/Philippines_Campaign_\(1944%E2%80%931945\) "Philippines
Campaign \(1944–1945\)"), [clearing Leyte](/wiki/Battle_of_Leyte "Battle of
Leyte") by the end of April 1945. They [landed on Luzon](/wiki/Battle_of_Luzon
"Battle of Luzon") in January 1945 and [recaptured
Manila](/wiki/Battle_of_Manila_\(1945\) "Battle of Manila \(1945\)") in March
following a battle which reduced the city to ruins. Fighting continued on
Luzon, [Mindanao](/wiki/Battle_of_Mindanao "Battle of Mindanao"), and other
islands of the Philippines until the [end of the
war](/wiki/End_of_World_War_II_in_Asia "End of World War II in Asia").[275]
Meanwhile, the [United States Army Air
Forces](/wiki/United_States_Army_Air_Forces "United States Army Air Forces")
(USAAF) were destroying strategic and populated cities and towns in Japan in
an effort to destroy Japanese war industry and civilian morale. On the night
of 9–10 March, USAAF [B-29](/wiki/Boeing_B-29_Superfortress "Boeing B-29
Superfortress") [bombers](/wiki/Bomber "Bomber") [struck
Tokyo](/wiki/Bombing_of_Tokyo "Bombing of Tokyo") with thousands of
[incendiary bombs](/wiki/Incendiary_device "Incendiary device"), which killed
100,000 civilians and destroyed 16 square miles (41 km2) within a few hours.
Over the next five months, the USAAF [firebombed a total of 67 Japanese
cities](/wiki/Air_raids_on_Japan "Air raids on Japan"), killing 393,000
civilians and destroying 65% of built-up areas.[276]

In May 1945, Australian troops [landed in
Borneo](/wiki/Borneo_campaign_\(1945\) "Borneo campaign \(1945\)"),
overrunning the oilfields there. British, American, and Chinese forces
defeated the Japanese in northern [Burma](/wiki/Burma_Campaign "Burma
Campaign") in March, and the British pushed on to reach
[Rangoon](/wiki/Rangoon "Rangoon") by 3 May.[277] Chinese forces started to
counterattack in [Battle of West Hunan](/wiki/Battle_of_West_Hunan "Battle of
West Hunan") that occurred between 6 April and 7 June 1945. American naval and
amphibious forces also moved towards Japan, taking [Iwo
Jima](/wiki/Battle_of_Iwo_Jima "Battle of Iwo Jima") by March, and
[Okinawa](/wiki/Battle_of_Okinawa "Battle of Okinawa") by the end of
June.[278] At the same time, American submarines [cut
off](/wiki/Allied_submarines_in_the_Pacific_War "Allied submarines in the
Pacific War") Japanese imports, drastically reducing Japan's ability to supply
its overseas forces.[279]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Shigemitsu-signs-
surrender.jpg/220px-Shigemitsu-signs-surrender.jpg)](/wiki/File:Shigemitsu-
signs-surrender.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Shigemitsu-signs-surrender.jpg "Enlarge")

Japanese foreign affairs minister [Mamoru Shigemitsu](/wiki/Mamoru_Shigemitsu
"Mamoru Shigemitsu") signs the [Japanese Instrument of
Surrender](/wiki/Japanese_Instrument_of_Surrender "Japanese Instrument of
Surrender") on board [USS  _Missouri_](/wiki/USS_Missouri_\(BB-63\) "USS
Missouri \(BB-63\)"), 2 September 1945

On 11 July, Allied leaders [met in Potsdam, Germany](/wiki/Potsdam_Conference
"Potsdam Conference"). They [confirmed earlier
agreements](/wiki/Potsdam_Agreement "Potsdam Agreement") about Germany,[280]
and reiterated the demand for unconditional surrender of all Japanese forces
by Japan, specifically stating that "the alternative for Japan is prompt and
utter destruction".[281] During this conference, the [United Kingdom held its
general election](/wiki/United_Kingdom_general_election,_1945 "United Kingdom
general election, 1945"), and [Clement Attlee](/wiki/Clement_Attlee "Clement
Attlee") replaced Churchill as Prime Minister.[282]

The Allies called for unconditional Japanese surrender in the [Potsdam
Declaration](/wiki/Potsdam_Declaration "Potsdam Declaration") of 27 July, but
the Japanese government rejected the call. In early August, the USAAF [dropped
atomic bombs](/wiki/Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki "Atomic bombings
of Hiroshima and Nagasaki") on the Japanese cities of
[Hiroshima](/wiki/Hiroshima "Hiroshima") and [Nagasaki](/wiki/Nagasaki
"Nagasaki"). The Allies justified the atomic bombings as a military necessity
to avoid [invading the Japanese home islands](/wiki/Operation_Downfall
"Operation Downfall") which would cost the lives of between 250,000 and
500,000 Allied servicemen and millions of Japanese troops and civilians.[283]
Between the two bombings, the Soviets, pursuant to the Yalta agreement,
[invaded Japanese-held Manchuria](/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Manchuria "Soviet
invasion of Manchuria"), and quickly defeated the [Kwantung
Army](/wiki/Kwantung_Army "Kwantung Army"), which was the largest Japanese
fighting force.[284][285] The Red Army also captured [Sakhalin](/wiki/Sakhalin
"Sakhalin") Island and the [Kuril Islands](/wiki/Kuril_Islands "Kuril
Islands"). On 15 August 1945, [Japan surrendered](/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan
"Surrender of Japan"), with the [surrender
documents](/wiki/Japanese_Instrument_of_Surrender "Japanese Instrument of
Surrender") finally signed at [Tokyo Bay](/wiki/Tokyo_Bay "Tokyo Bay") on the
deck of the American battleship [USS _Missouri_](/wiki/USS_Missouri_\(BB-63\)
"USS Missouri \(BB-63\)") on 2 September 1945, ending the war.[286]

## Aftermath

Main articles: [Aftermath of World War II](/wiki/Aftermath_of_World_War_II
"Aftermath of World War II") and [Consequences of
Nazism](/wiki/Consequences_of_Nazism "Consequences of Nazism")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Ww2_170.jpg/220px-
Ww2_170.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ww2_170.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ww2_170.jpg "Enlarge")

Defendants at the [Nuremberg trials](/wiki/Nuremberg_trials "Nuremberg
trials"), where the Allied forces prosecuted prominent members of the
political, military, judicial and economic leadership of [Nazi
Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany") for [crimes against
humanity](/wiki/Crimes_against_humanity "Crimes against humanity")

The Allies established occupation administrations in [Austria](/wiki/Allied-
occupied_Austria "Allied-occupied Austria") and [Germany](/wiki/Allied-
occupied_Germany "Allied-occupied Germany"). The former became a neutral
state, non-aligned with any political bloc. The latter was divided into
western and eastern occupation zones controlled by the Western Allies and the
USSR, accordingly. A [denazification](/wiki/Denazification "Denazification")
programme in Germany led to the [prosecution of Nazi war
criminals](/wiki/Nuremberg_trials "Nuremberg trials") and the removal of ex-
Nazis from power, although this policy moved towards amnesty and re-
integration of ex-Nazis into West German society.[287]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Destroyed_Warsaw%2C_capital_of_Poland%2C_January_1945.jpg/220px-
Destroyed_Warsaw%2C_capital_of_Poland%2C_January_1945.jpg)](/wiki/File:Destroyed_Warsaw,_capital_of_Poland,_January_1945.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Destroyed_Warsaw,_capital_of_Poland,_January_1945.jpg "Enlarge")

Ruins of [Warsaw](/wiki/Warsaw "Warsaw") in January 1945, after the
[deliberate destruction of the city](/wiki/Planned_destruction_of_Warsaw
"Planned destruction of Warsaw") by the occupying German forces

Germany lost a quarter of its pre-war (1937) territory. Among the eastern
territories, [Silesia](/wiki/Silesia "Silesia"), [Neumark](/wiki/Neumark
"Neumark") and most of [Pomerania](/wiki/Pomerania "Pomerania") were taken
over by Poland, [East Prussia](/wiki/East_Prussia "East Prussia") was divided
between Poland and the USSR, followed by the [expulsion of the 9 million
Germans](/wiki/Flight_and_expulsion_of_Germans_\(1944%E2%80%9350\) "Flight and
expulsion of Germans \(1944–50\)") from these provinces, as well as the
expulsion of 3 million Germans from the [Sudetenland](/wiki/Sudetenland
"Sudetenland") in Czechoslovakia to Germany. By the 1950s, every fifth West
German was a refugee from the east. The Soviet Union also took over the Polish
provinces east of the [Curzon line](/wiki/Curzon_line "Curzon line"), from
which [2 million Poles were
expelled](/wiki/Polish_population_transfers_\(1944%E2%80%931946\) "Polish
population transfers \(1944–1946\)");[288] north-east Romania,[289][290] parts
of eastern Finland,[291] and the three [Baltic states](/wiki/Baltic_states
"Baltic states") were also [incorporated into the
USSR](/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_the_Baltic_states_\(1944\) "Soviet occupation
of the Baltic states \(1944\)").[292][293]

In an effort to maintain [world peace](/wiki/World_peace "World peace"),[294]
the Allies formed the [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations"),
which officially came into existence on 24 October 1945,[295] and adopted the
[Universal Declaration of Human
Rights](/wiki/Universal_Declaration_of_Human_Rights "Universal Declaration of
Human Rights") in 1948, as a common standard for all [member
nations](/wiki/Member_states_of_the_United_Nations "Member states of the
United Nations").[296] The great powers that were the victors of the
war—France, China, Britain, the Soviet Union and the United States—became the
[permanent
members](/wiki/Permanent_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council
"Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council") of the UN's
[Security Council](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council "United Nations
Security Council").[7] The five permanent members remain so to the present,
although there have been two seat changes,
[between](/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_2758 "United
Nations General Assembly Resolution 2758") the [Republic of
China](/wiki/Taiwan "Taiwan") and the [People's Republic of China](/wiki/China
"China") in 1971, and between the Soviet Union and its [successor
state](/wiki/Successor_state "Successor state"), the [Russian
Federation](/wiki/Russia "Russia"), following the [dissolution of the Soviet
Union](/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union "Dissolution of the Soviet
Union") in 1991. The alliance between the Western Allies and the Soviet Union
had begun to deteriorate even before the war was over.[297]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/EasternBloc_BorderChange38-48.svg/180px-
EasternBloc_BorderChange38-48.svg.png)](/wiki/File:EasternBloc_BorderChange38-48.svg)

[](/wiki/File:EasternBloc_BorderChange38-48.svg "Enlarge")

Post-war Soviet territorial expansion resulted in
[Central](/wiki/Central_Europe "Central Europe") and [Eastern
European](/wiki/Eastern_Europe "Eastern Europe") border changes, the creation
of a [Communist Bloc](/wiki/Eastern_Bloc "Eastern Bloc") and start of the
[Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War")

Germany had been _de facto_ divided, and two independent states, the [Federal
Republic of Germany](/wiki/West_Germany "West Germany") and the [German
Democratic Republic](/wiki/East_Germany "East Germany")[298] were created
within the borders of [Allied](/wiki/Bizone "Bizone") and [Soviet occupation
zones](/wiki/Soviet_occupation_zone "Soviet occupation zone"), accordingly.
The rest of Europe was also divided into Western and Soviet [spheres of
influence](/wiki/Spheres_of_influence "Spheres of influence").[299] Most
eastern and central European countries fell into [the Soviet
sphere](/wiki/Eastern_Bloc "Eastern Bloc"), which led to establishment of
Communist-led regimes, with full or partial support of the Soviet occupation
authorities. As a result, [East Germany](/wiki/East_Germany "East
Germany"),[300] [Poland](/wiki/Polish_People%27s_Republic "Polish People's
Republic"), [Hungary](/wiki/Hungarian_People%27s_Republic "Hungarian People's
Republic"), [Romania](/wiki/Socialist_Republic_of_Romania "Socialist Republic
of Romania"), [Czechoslovakia](/wiki/Czechoslovak_Socialist_Republic
"Czechoslovak Socialist Republic"), and
[Albania](/wiki/People%27s_Socialist_Republic_of_Albania "People's Socialist
Republic of Albania")[301] became Soviet [satellite
states](/wiki/Satellite_state "Satellite state"). Communist
[Yugoslavia](/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia "Socialist Federal
Republic of Yugoslavia") conducted a fully [independent policy](/wiki/Non-
Aligned_Movement "Non-Aligned Movement"), causing [tension with the
USSR](/wiki/Tito%E2%80%93Stalin_Split "Tito–Stalin Split").[302]

Post-war division of the world was formalised by two international military
alliances, the United States-led [NATO](/wiki/NATO "NATO") and the Soviet-led
[Warsaw Pact](/wiki/Warsaw_Pact "Warsaw Pact");[303] the long period of
political tensions and military competition between them, the [Cold
War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War"), would be accompanied by an unprecedented
[arms race](/wiki/Arms_race "Arms race") and [proxy wars](/wiki/Proxy_war
"Proxy war").[304]

In Asia, the United States led the [occupation of
Japan](/wiki/Occupation_of_Japan "Occupation of Japan") and [administrated
Japan's former islands in the Western
Pacific](/wiki/Trust_Territory_of_the_Pacific_Islands "Trust Territory of the
Pacific Islands"), while the Soviets annexed [Sakhalin](/wiki/Sakhalin
"Sakhalin") and the [Kuril Islands](/wiki/Kuril_Islands "Kuril Islands").[305]
[Korea](/wiki/Korea "Korea"), formerly [under Japanese
rule](/wiki/Korea_under_Japanese_rule "Korea under Japanese rule"), was
[divided and occupied](/wiki/Division_of_Korea "Division of Korea") by the
Soviet Union in the [North](/wiki/North_Korea "North Korea") and the US in the
[South](/wiki/South_Korea "South Korea") between 1945 and 1948. Separate
republics emerged on both sides of the 38th parallel in 1948, each claiming to
be the legitimate government for all of Korea, which led ultimately to the
[Korean War](/wiki/Korean_War "Korean War").[306]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Declaration_of_State_of_Israel_1948.jpg/220px-
Declaration_of_State_of_Israel_1948.jpg)](/wiki/File:Declaration_of_State_of_Israel_1948.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Declaration_of_State_of_Israel_1948.jpg "Enlarge")

[David Ben-Gurion](/wiki/David_Ben-Gurion "David Ben-Gurion") proclaiming the
[Israeli Declaration of
Independence](/wiki/Israeli_Declaration_of_Independence "Israeli Declaration
of Independence") at the [Independence
Hall](/wiki/Independence_Hall_\(Israel\) "Independence Hall \(Israel\)"), 14
May 1948

In China, nationalist and communist forces resumed [the civil
war](/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War "Chinese Civil War") in June 1946. Communist
forces were victorious and established the People's Republic of China on the
mainland, while nationalist forces retreated to [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan
"Taiwan") in 1949.[307] In the Middle East, the Arab rejection of the [United
Nations Partition Plan for
Palestine](/wiki/United_Nations_Partition_Plan_for_Palestine "United Nations
Partition Plan for Palestine") and the [creation of
Israel](/wiki/Creation_of_Israel "Creation of Israel") marked the escalation
of the [Arab–Israeli conflict](/wiki/Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_conflict
"Arab–Israeli conflict"). While European powers attempted to retain some or
all of their [colonial empires](/wiki/Colonial_empire "Colonial empire"),
their losses of prestige and resources during the war rendered this
unsuccessful, leading to [decolonisation](/wiki/Decolonization
"Decolonization").[308][309]

The global economy suffered heavily from the war, although participating
nations were affected differently. The US emerged much richer than any other
nation; it had a [baby boom](/wiki/Post%E2%80%93World_War_II_baby_boom
"Post–World War II baby boom") and by 1950 its gross domestic product per
person was much higher than that of any of the other powers and it dominated
the world economy.[310] The UK and US pursued a policy of [industrial
disarmament in Western
Germany](/wiki/Allied_plans_for_German_industry_after_World_War_II "Allied
plans for German industry after World War II") in the years 1945–1948.[311]
Because of international trade interdependencies this led to European economic
stagnation and delayed European recovery for several years.[312][313]

Recovery began with the mid-1948 [currency reform in Western
Germany](/wiki/Deutsche_Mark "Deutsche Mark"), and was sped up by the
liberalisation of European economic policy that the [Marshall
Plan](/wiki/Marshall_Plan "Marshall Plan") (1948–1951) both directly and
indirectly caused.[314][315] The post-1948 West German recovery has been
called the [German economic miracle](/wiki/Wirtschaftswunder#West_Germany
"Wirtschaftswunder").[316] Italy also experienced an [economic
boom](/wiki/Italian_economic_miracle "Italian economic miracle")[317] and the
[French economy rebounded](/wiki/Trente_Glorieuses "Trente Glorieuses").[318]
By contrast, the United Kingdom was in a state of economic ruin,[319] and
although it received a quarter of the total Marshall Plan assistance, more
than any other European country,[320] continued relative economic decline for
decades.[321]

The Soviet Union, despite enormous human and material losses, also experienced
rapid increase in production in the immediate post-war era.[322] Japan
experienced [incredibly rapid](/wiki/Japanese_post-war_economic_miracle
"Japanese post-war economic miracle") economic growth, becoming one of the
most powerful economies in the world by the 1980s.[323] China returned to its
pre-war industrial production by 1952.[324]

## Impact

### Casualties and war crimes

Main articles: [World War II casualties](/wiki/World_War_II_casualties "World
War II casualties"), [War crimes during World War
II](/wiki/War_crimes_during_World_War_II "War crimes during World War II"),
[War crimes in occupied Poland during World War
II](/wiki/War_crimes_in_occupied_Poland_during_World_War_II "War crimes in
occupied Poland during World War II"), [German war
crimes](/wiki/German_war_crimes "German war crimes"), [War crimes of the
Wehrmacht](/wiki/War_crimes_of_the_Wehrmacht "War crimes of the Wehrmacht"),
[Italian war crimes](/wiki/Italian_war_crimes "Italian war crimes"), [Japanese
war crimes](/wiki/Japanese_war_crimes "Japanese war crimes"), [Allied war
crimes during World War II](/wiki/Allied_war_crimes_during_World_War_II
"Allied war crimes during World War II"), and [Soviet war
crimes](/wiki/Soviet_war_crimes "Soviet war crimes")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/World_War_II_Casualties2.svg/425px-
World_War_II_Casualties2.svg.png)](/wiki/File:World_War_II_Casualties2.svg)

[](/wiki/File:World_War_II_Casualties2.svg "Enlarge")

World War II deaths

Estimates for the total number of casualties in the war vary, because many
deaths went unrecorded. Most suggest that some 60 million people died in the
war, including about [20 million military
personnel](/wiki/Battle_casualties_of_World_War_II "Battle casualties of World
War II") and 40 million civilians.[325][326][327] Many of the civilians died
because of deliberate [genocide](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide"),
[massacres](/wiki/List_of_massacres "List of massacres"), [mass-
bombings](/wiki/Strategic_bombing_during_World_War_II "Strategic bombing
during World War II"), [disease](/wiki/Infectious_disease "Infectious
disease"), and [starvation](/wiki/Starvation "Starvation").

The Soviet Union lost around 27 million people during the war,[328] including
8.7 million military and 19 million civilian deaths. The largest portion of
military dead were 5.7 million ethnic [Russians](/wiki/Russians "Russians"),
followed by 1.3 million ethnic [Ukrainians](/wiki/Ukrainians
"Ukrainians").[329] A quarter of the people in the Soviet Union were wounded
or killed.[330] Germany sustained 5.3 million military losses, mostly on the
Eastern Front and during the final battles in Germany.[331]

Of the total number of deaths in World War II, approximately 85 per
cent—mostly Soviet and Chinese—were on the Allied side and 15 per cent were on
the Axis side.[332] Many of these deaths were caused by war crimes [committed
by German](/wiki/War_crimes_of_the_Wehrmacht "War crimes of the Wehrmacht")
and [Japanese forces](/wiki/Japanese_war_crimes "Japanese war crimes") in
occupied territories. An estimated 11[333] to 17 million[334] civilians died
either as a direct or as an indirect result of Nazi racist policies, including
[the Holocaust](/wiki/The_Holocaust "The Holocaust") of around 6 million Jews,
half of whom were Polish citizens, along with a further minimum 1.9 million
ethnic Poles.[335][336] Millions of other Slavs (including Russians,
Ukrainians and Belarusians), [Roma](/wiki/Romani_people "Romani people"),
[homosexuals](/wiki/Persecution_of_homosexuals_in_Nazi_Germany_and_the_Holocaust
"Persecution of homosexuals in Nazi Germany and the Holocaust"), and other
ethnic and minority groups were also killed.[337][334] Hundreds of thousands
(varying estimates) of ethnic [Serbs](/wiki/Serbs "Serbs"), along with gypsies
and Jews, were murdered by the Axis-aligned Croatian
[Ustaše](/wiki/Usta%C5%A1e "Ustaše") in [Yugoslavia](/wiki/Yugoslavia
"Yugoslavia"),[338] and [retribution-related
killings](/wiki/Bleiburg_repatriations "Bleiburg repatriations") were
committed just after the war ended.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Chinese_civilians_to_be_buried_alive.jpg/220px-
Chinese_civilians_to_be_buried_alive.jpg)](/wiki/File:Chinese_civilians_to_be_buried_alive.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Chinese_civilians_to_be_buried_alive.jpg "Enlarge")

Chinese civilians being buried alive by soldiers of the [Imperial Japanese
Army](/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Army "Imperial Japanese Army"), during the
[Nanking Massacre](/wiki/Nanking_Massacre "Nanking Massacre"), December 1937

In Asia and the Pacific, between 3 million and more than 10 million civilians,
mostly Chinese (estimated at 7.5 million[339]), were killed by the Japanese
occupation forces.[340] The best-known Japanese atrocity was the [Nanking
Massacre](/wiki/Nanking_Massacre "Nanking Massacre"), in which fifty to three
hundred thousand Chinese civilians were raped and murdered.[341] Mitsuyoshi
Himeta reported that 2.7 million casualties occurred during the _[Sankō
Sakusen](/wiki/Three_Alls_Policy "Three Alls Policy")_. General [Yasuji
Okamura](/wiki/Yasuji_Okamura "Yasuji Okamura") implemented the policy in
Heipei and [Shantung](/wiki/Shantung "Shantung").[342]

Axis forces employed [biological](/wiki/Biological_warfare "Biological
warfare") and [chemical weapons](/wiki/Chemical_warfare "Chemical warfare").
The [Imperial Japanese Army](/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Army "Imperial Japanese
Army") used a variety of such weapons during its [invasion and occupation of
China](/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War "Second Sino-Japanese War") (_see[Unit
731](/wiki/Unit_731 "Unit 731")_)[343][344] and in [early conflicts against
the Soviets](/wiki/Battles_of_Khalkhin_Gol "Battles of Khalkhin Gol").[345]
Both the Germans and [Japanese
tested](/wiki/Japanese_human_experimentation_on_the_Chinese "Japanese human
experimentation on the Chinese") such weapons against civilians[346] and,
sometimes on [prisoners of war](/wiki/Prisoner_of_war "Prisoner of war").[347]

The Soviet Union was responsible for the [Katyn massacre](/wiki/Katyn_massacre
"Katyn massacre") of 22,000 Polish officers,[348] and the imprisonment or
execution of thousands of political prisoners by the [NKVD](/wiki/NKVD
"NKVD"),[349] in the [Baltic states](/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Baltic_states
"Occupation of the Baltic states"), and [eastern
Poland](/wiki/Territories_of_Poland_annexed_by_the_Soviet_Union "Territories
of Poland annexed by the Soviet Union") annexed by the Red Army.

The mass-bombing of cities in Europe and Asia has often been called a war
crime. However, no [positive](/wiki/Positive_international_law "Positive
international law") or specific [customary](/wiki/Customary_international_law
"Customary international law") [international humanitarian
law](/wiki/International_humanitarian_law "International humanitarian law")
with respect to [aerial warfare](/wiki/Aerial_warfare "Aerial warfare")
existed before or during World War II.[350]

### Genocide, concentration camps, and slave labour

Main articles: [Genocide](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide"), [The
Holocaust](/wiki/The_Holocaust "The Holocaust"), [Nazi concentration
camps](/wiki/Nazi_concentration_camps "Nazi concentration camps"),
[Extermination camp](/wiki/Extermination_camp "Extermination camp"), [Forced
labour under German rule during World War
II](/wiki/Forced_labour_under_German_rule_during_World_War_II "Forced labour
under German rule during World War II"), [Kidnapping of children by Nazi
Germany](/wiki/Kidnapping_of_children_by_Nazi_Germany "Kidnapping of children
by Nazi Germany"), and [Nazi human
experimentation](/wiki/Nazi_human_experimentation "Nazi human
experimentation")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/The_Liberation_of_Bergen-
belsen_Concentration_Camp%2C_April_1945_BU4031.jpg/220px-
The_Liberation_of_Bergen-
belsen_Concentration_Camp%2C_April_1945_BU4031.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Liberation_of_Bergen-
belsen_Concentration_Camp,_April_1945_BU4031.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_Liberation_of_Bergen-
belsen_Concentration_Camp,_April_1945_BU4031.jpg "Enlarge")

[Schutzstaffel](/wiki/Schutzstaffel "Schutzstaffel") (SS) female camp guards
remove prisoners' bodies from lorries and carry them to a mass grave, inside
the German [Bergen-Belsen concentration camp](/wiki/Bergen-
Belsen_concentration_camp "Bergen-Belsen concentration camp"), 1945

The German government led by [Adolf Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler")
and the [Nazi Party](/wiki/Nazi_Party "Nazi Party") was responsible for [the
Holocaust](/wiki/The_Holocaust "The Holocaust"), the killing of approximately
6 million Jews, as well as 2.7 million ethnic
[Poles](/wiki/Nazi_crimes_against_the_Polish_nation "Nazi crimes against the
Polish nation"),[351] and 4 million others who were deemed "[unworthy of
life](/wiki/Life_unworthy_of_life "Life unworthy of life")" (including the
[disabled](/wiki/Disability "Disability") and [mentally
ill](/wiki/Mental_disorder "Mental disorder"), [Soviet prisoners of
war](/wiki/German_mistreatment_of_Soviet_prisoners_of_war "German mistreatment
of Soviet prisoners of war"), [homosexuals](/wiki/Homosexuals "Homosexuals"),
[Freemasons](/wiki/Freemasons "Freemasons"), [Jehovah's
Witnesses](/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses "Jehovah's Witnesses"), and
[Romani](/wiki/Romani_people "Romani people")) as part of a programme of
deliberate extermination. About 12 million, most of whom were [Eastern
Europeans](/wiki/Ostarbeiter "Ostarbeiter"), were employed in the German war
economy as [forced
labourers](/wiki/Forced_labour_under_German_rule_during_World_War_II "Forced
labour under German rule during World War II").[352]

In addition to [Nazi concentration camps](/wiki/Nazi_concentration_camps "Nazi
concentration camps"), the Soviet [gulags](/wiki/Gulag "Gulag") ([labour
camps](/wiki/Labor_camp "Labor camp")) led to the death of citizens of
occupied countries such as Poland, Lithuania, Latvia, and Estonia, as well as
German [prisoners of war](/wiki/Prisoner_of_war "Prisoner of war") (POWs) and
even Soviet citizens who had been or were thought to be supporters of the
Nazis.[353] Sixty per cent of [Soviet POWs of the
Germans](/wiki/German_mistreatment_of_Soviet_prisoners_of_war "German
mistreatment of Soviet prisoners of war") died during the war.[354] [Richard
Overy](/wiki/Richard_Overy "Richard Overy") gives the number of 5.7 million
Soviet POWs. Of those, 57 per cent died or were killed, a total of 3.6
million.[355] Soviet ex-POWs and repatriated civilians were treated with great
suspicion as potential Nazi collaborators, and some of them were sent to the
Gulag upon being checked by the NKVD.[356]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Czeslawa_Kwoka_-
_Brasse.jpg/220px-Czeslawa_Kwoka_-_Brasse.jpg)](/wiki/File:Czeslawa_Kwoka_-
_Brasse.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Czeslawa_Kwoka_-_Brasse.jpg "Enlarge")

Prisoner identity photograph taken by the German [SS](/wiki/SS "SS") of a
[Polish girl deported as forced labour](/wiki/Czes%C5%82awa_Kwoka "Czesława
Kwoka") to [Auschwitz](/wiki/Auschwitz "Auschwitz"), December 1942

Japanese [prisoner-of-war camps](/wiki/Prisoner-of-war_camp "Prisoner-of-war
camp"), many of which were used as labour camps, also had high death rates.
The [International Military Tribunal for the Far
East](/wiki/International_Military_Tribunal_for_the_Far_East "International
Military Tribunal for the Far East") found the death rate of Western prisoners
was 27.1 per cent (for American POWs, 37 per cent),[357] seven times that of
POWs under the Germans and Italians.[358] While 37,583 prisoners from the UK,
28,500 from the Netherlands, and 14,473 from the United States were released
after the [surrender of Japan](/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan "Surrender of Japan"),
the number of Chinese released was only 56.[359]

According to historian Zhifen Ju, at least five million Chinese civilians from
northern China and Manchukuo were enslaved between 1935 and 1941 by the [East
Asia Development Board](/wiki/East_Asia_Development_Board "East Asia
Development Board"), or _Kōain_ , for work in mines and war industries. After
1942, the number reached 10 million.[360] The US Library of Congress estimates
that in [Java](/wiki/Java "Java"), between 4 and 10 million
_[rōmusha](/wiki/R%C5%8Dmusha "Rōmusha")_ (Japanese: "manual labourers"), were
forced to work by the Japanese military. About 270,000 of these Javanese
labourers were sent to other Japanese-held areas in South East Asia, and only
52,000 were repatriated to Java.[361]

On 19 February 1942, Roosevelt signed [Executive Order
9066](/wiki/Executive_Order_9066 "Executive Order 9066"), interning about
100,000 Japanese living on the West Coast. Canada had a similar
programme.[362][363] In addition, 14,000 German and Italian citizens who had
been assessed as being security risks were also interned.[364]

In accordance with the Allied agreement made at the [Yalta
Conference](/wiki/Yalta_Conference "Yalta Conference") millions of POWs and
civilians were used as [forced labour by the Soviet
Union](/wiki/Foreign_forced_labor_in_the_Soviet_Union "Foreign forced labor in
the Soviet Union").[365] In Hungary's case, [Hungarians were forced to work
for the Soviet Union](/wiki/Forced_labor_of_Hungarians_in_the_Soviet_Union
"Forced labor of Hungarians in the Soviet Union") until 1955.[366]

### Occupation

Main articles: [German-occupied Europe](/wiki/German-occupied_Europe "German-
occupied Europe"), [Lebensraum](/wiki/Lebensraum "Lebensraum"),
[Untermensch](/wiki/Untermensch "Untermensch"), [Collaboration with the Axis
Powers during World War
II](/wiki/Collaboration_with_the_Axis_Powers_during_World_War_II
"Collaboration with the Axis Powers during World War II"), [Resistance during
World War II](/wiki/Resistance_during_World_War_II "Resistance during World
War II"), and [Nazi plunder](/wiki/Nazi_plunder "Nazi plunder")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Palmiry_before_execution.jpg/220px-
Palmiry_before_execution.jpg)](/wiki/File:Palmiry_before_execution.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Palmiry_before_execution.jpg "Enlarge")

Polish civilians wearing blindfolds photographed just before [their execution
by German soldiers in Palmiry forest](/wiki/Palmiry_massacre "Palmiry
massacre"), 1940

In Europe, occupation came under two forms. In Western, Northern, and Central
Europe (France, Norway, Denmark, the Low Countries, and the [annexed portions
of Czechoslovakia](/wiki/Protectorate_of_Bohemia_and_Moravia "Protectorate of
Bohemia and Moravia")) Germany established economic policies through which it
collected roughly 69.5 billion reichmarks (27.8 billion US Dollars) by the end
of the war, this figure does not include the [sizeable
plunder](/wiki/Nazi_plunder "Nazi plunder") of industrial products, military
equipment, raw materials and other goods.[367] Thus, the income from occupied
nations was over 40 per cent of the income Germany collected from taxation, a
figure which increased to nearly 40 per cent of total German income as the war
went on.[368]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Bundesarchiv_Bild_101I-031-2436-03A%2C_Russland%2C_Hinrichtung_von_Partisanen_retouched.jpg/220px-
Bundesarchiv_Bild_101I-031-2436-03A%2C_Russland%2C_Hinrichtung_von_Partisanen_retouched.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_101I-031-2436-03A,_Russland,_Hinrichtung_von_Partisanen_retouched.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_101I-031-2436-03A,_Russland,_Hinrichtung_von_Partisanen_retouched.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Russian Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Russian_Academy_of_Sciences "Russian
Academy of Sciences") reported in 1995 [civilian victims in the Soviet
Union](/wiki/World_War_II_casualties_of_the_Soviet_Union "World War II
casualties of the Soviet Union") at German hands totalled 13.7 million dead,
twenty percent of the 68 million persons in the occupied USSR

In the East, the intended gains of _[Lebensraum](/wiki/Lebensraum
"Lebensraum")_ were never attained as fluctuating front-lines and Soviet
[scorched earth](/wiki/Scorched_earth "Scorched earth") policies denied
resources to the German invaders.[369] Unlike in the West, the [Nazi racial
policy](/wiki/Racial_policy_of_Nazi_Germany "Racial policy of Nazi Germany")
encouraged extreme brutality against what it considered to be the "[inferior
people](/wiki/Untermensch "Untermensch")" of Slavic descent; most German
advances were thus followed by [mass executions](/wiki/Generalplan_Ost
"Generalplan Ost").[370] Although [resistance
groups](/wiki/Resistance_during_World_War_II "Resistance during World War II")
formed in most occupied territories, they did not significantly hamper German
operations in either the East[371] or the West[372] until late 1943.

In Asia, Japan termed nations under its occupation as being part of the
[Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere](/wiki/Greater_East_Asia_Co-
Prosperity_Sphere "Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere"), essentially a
Japanese [hegemony](/wiki/Hegemony "Hegemony") which it claimed was for
purposes of liberating colonised peoples.[373] Although Japanese forces were
originally welcomed as liberators from European domination in some
territories, their excessive brutality turned local public opinion against
them within weeks.[374] During Japan's initial conquest it captured 4,000,000
barrels (640,000 m3) of oil (~5.5×105 tonnes) left behind by retreating Allied
forces, and by 1943 was able to get production in the Dutch East Indies up to
50 million barrels (~6.8×10~~^~~ 6 t), 76 per cent of its 1940 output
rate.[374]

### Home fronts and production

Main articles: [Military production during World War
II](/wiki/Military_production_during_World_War_II "Military production during
World War II") and [Home front during World War
II](/wiki/Home_front_during_World_War_II "Home front during World War II")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/WorldWarII-GDP-
Relations-Allies-Axis-simple.svg/330px-WorldWarII-GDP-Relations-Allies-Axis-
simple.svg.png)](/wiki/File:WorldWarII-GDP-Relations-Allies-Axis-simple.svg)

[](/wiki/File:WorldWarII-GDP-Relations-Allies-Axis-simple.svg "Enlarge")

Allied to Axis GDP ratio

In Europe, before the outbreak of the war, the Allies had significant
advantages in both population and economics. In 1938, the Western Allies
(United Kingdom, France, Poland and British Dominions) had a 30 per cent
larger population and a 30 per cent higher gross domestic product than the
European Axis powers (Germany and Italy); if colonies are included, it then
gives the Allies more than a 5:1 advantage in population and nearly 2:1
advantage in GDP.[375] In Asia at the same time, China had roughly six times
the population of Japan, but only an 89 per cent higher GDP; this is reduced
to three times the population and only a 38 per cent higher GDP if Japanese
colonies are included.[375]

The United States provided about two-thirds of all the ordnance used by the
Allies in terms of warships, transports, warplanes, artillery, tanks, trucks,
and ammunition.[376] Though the Allies' economic and population advantages
were largely mitigated during the initial rapid blitzkrieg attacks of Germany
and Japan, they became the decisive factor by 1942, after the United States
and Soviet Union joined the Allies, as the war largely settled into one of
[attrition](/wiki/Attrition_warfare "Attrition warfare").[377] While the
Allies' ability to out-produce the Axis is often attributed to the Allies
having more access to natural resources, other factors, such as Germany and
Japan's reluctance to employ women in the [labour force](/wiki/Labour_force
"Labour force"),[378] Allied [strategic
bombing](/wiki/Strategic_bombing_during_World_War_II "Strategic bombing during
World War II"),[379] and Germany's late shift to a [war
economy](/wiki/War_economy "War economy")[380] contributed significantly.
Additionally, neither Germany nor Japan planned to fight a protracted war, and
were not equipped to do so.[381] To improve their production, Germany and
Japan used millions of [slave labourers](/wiki/Slave_labour "Slave
labour");[382] [Germany
used](/wiki/Forced_labour_under_German_rule_during_World_War_II "Forced labour
under German rule during World War II") about 12 million people, mostly from
Eastern Europe,[352] while [Japan used](/wiki/Slavery_in_Japan "Slavery in
Japan") more than 18 million people in Far East Asia.[360][361]

### Advances in technology and warfare

Main article: [Technology during World War
II](/wiki/Technology_during_World_War_II "Technology during World War II")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Boeing-
Whichata_B-29_Assembly_Line_-_1944.jpg/225px-Boeing-
Whichata_B-29_Assembly_Line_-_1944.jpg)](/wiki/File:Boeing-
Whichata_B-29_Assembly_Line_-_1944.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Boeing-Whichata_B-29_Assembly_Line_-_1944.jpg "Enlarge")

[B-29 Superfortress](/wiki/Boeing_B-29_Superfortress "Boeing B-29
Superfortress") [strategic bombers](/wiki/Strategic_bombers "Strategic
bombers") on the [Boeing](/wiki/Boeing "Boeing") assembly line in [Wichita,
Kansas](/wiki/Wichita,_Kansas "Wichita, Kansas"), 1944

Aircraft were used for [reconnaissance](/wiki/Reconnaissance_aircraft
"Reconnaissance aircraft"), as [fighters](/wiki/Fighter_aircraft "Fighter
aircraft"), [bombers](/wiki/Bomber "Bomber"), and [ground-
support](/wiki/Close_air_support "Close air support"), and each role was
advanced considerably. Innovation included [airlift](/wiki/Airlift "Airlift")
(the capability to quickly move limited high-priority supplies, equipment, and
personnel);[383] and of [strategic bombing](/wiki/Strategic_bombing "Strategic
bombing") (the bombing of enemy industrial and population centres to destroy
the enemy's ability to wage war).[384] [Anti-aircraft weaponry](/wiki/Anti-
aircraft_warfare "Anti-aircraft warfare") also advanced, including defences
such as [radar](/wiki/Radar "Radar") and surface-to-air artillery, such as the
German [88 mm gun](/wiki/88_mm_gun "88 mm gun"). The use of the [jet
aircraft](/wiki/Jet_aircraft "Jet aircraft") was pioneered and, though late
introduction meant it had little impact, it led to jets becoming standard in
air forces worldwide.[385]

Advances were made in nearly every aspect of [naval
warfare](/wiki/Naval_warfare "Naval warfare"), most notably with aircraft
carriers and submarines. Although [aeronautical](/wiki/Aeronautics
"Aeronautics") warfare had relatively little success at the start of the war,
[actions at Taranto](/wiki/Battle_of_Taranto "Battle of Taranto"), [Pearl
Harbor](/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor "Attack on Pearl Harbor"), and the [Coral
Sea](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Coral_Sea "Battle of the Coral Sea") established the
carrier as the dominant capital ship in place of the
battleship.[386][387][388]

In the Atlantic, [escort carriers](/wiki/Escort_carrier "Escort carrier")
proved to be a vital part of Allied convoys, increasing the effective
protection radius and helping to close the [Mid-Atlantic gap](/wiki/Mid-
Atlantic_gap "Mid-Atlantic gap").[389] Carriers were also more economical than
battleships because of the relatively low cost of aircraft[390] and their not
requiring to be as heavily armoured.[391] Submarines, which had proved to be
an effective weapon during the [First World War](/wiki/World_War_I "World War
I"),[392] were anticipated by all sides to be important in the second. The
British focused development on [anti-submarine](/wiki/Anti-submarine_warfare
"Anti-submarine warfare") [weaponry](/wiki/Anti-submarine_weapon "Anti-
submarine weapon") and tactics, such as [sonar](/wiki/Sonar "Sonar") and
convoys, while Germany focused on improving its offensive capability, with
designs such as the [Type VII submarine](/wiki/German_Type_VII_submarine
"German Type VII submarine") and [wolfpack](/wiki/Wolfpack_\(naval_tactic\)
"Wolfpack \(naval tactic\)") tactics.[393] Gradually, improving Allied
technologies such as the [Leigh light](/wiki/Leigh_light "Leigh light"),
[hedgehog](/wiki/Hedgehog_\(weapon\) "Hedgehog \(weapon\)"),
[squid](/wiki/Squid_\(weapon\) "Squid \(weapon\)"), and [homing
torpedoes](/wiki/Mark_24_mine "Mark 24 mine") proved victorious.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Bundesarchiv_Bild_141-1880%2C_Peenem%C3%BCnde%2C_Start_einer_V2.jpg/200px-
Bundesarchiv_Bild_141-1880%2C_Peenem%C3%BCnde%2C_Start_einer_V2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_141-1880,_Peenem%C3%BCnde,_Start_einer_V2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_141-1880,_Peenem%C3%BCnde,_Start_einer_V2.jpg
"Enlarge")

A [V-2 rocket](/wiki/V-2_rocket "V-2 rocket") launched from a fixed site in
[Peenemünde](/wiki/Peenem%C3%BCnde "Peenemünde"), 21 June 1943

[Land warfare](/wiki/Land_warfare "Land warfare") changed from the static
front lines of World War I to increased mobility and [combined
arms](/wiki/Combined_arms "Combined arms"). The [tank](/wiki/Tank "Tank"),
which had been used predominantly for infantry support in the First World War,
had evolved into the primary weapon.[394] In the late 1930s, tank design was
considerably more advanced than it had been during World War I,[395] and
[advances continued throughout the war](/wiki/Tanks_in_World_War_II "Tanks in
