World War II") with increases in speed, armour and firepower.

At the start of the war, most commanders thought enemy tanks should be met by
tanks with superior specifications.[396] This idea was challenged by the poor
performance of the relatively light early tank guns against armour, and German
doctrine of avoiding tank-versus-tank combat. This, along with Germany's use
of combined arms, were among the key elements of their highly successful
blitzkrieg tactics across Poland and France.[394] Many means of [destroying
tanks](/wiki/Anti-tank_warfare "Anti-tank warfare"), including [indirect
artillery](/wiki/Indirect_fire "Indirect fire"), [anti-tank guns](/wiki/Anti-
tank_gun "Anti-tank gun") (both towed and [self-propelled](/wiki/Self-
propelled_gun "Self-propelled gun")), [mines](/wiki/Anti-tank_mine "Anti-tank
mine"), short-ranged infantry antitank weapons, and other tanks were
utilised.[396] Even with large-scale mechanisation, infantry remained the
backbone of all forces,[397] and throughout the war, most infantry were
equipped similarly to World War I.[398]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Trinity_device_readied.jpg/225px-
Trinity_device_readied.jpg)](/wiki/File:Trinity_device_readied.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Trinity_device_readied.jpg "Enlarge")

Nuclear _Gadget_ being raised to the top of the detonation "shot tower", at
[Alamogordo Bombing Range](/wiki/Alamogordo_Bombing_and_Gunnery_Range
"Alamogordo Bombing and Gunnery Range"); [Trinity nuclear
test](/wiki/Trinity_\(nuclear_test\) "Trinity \(nuclear test\)"), [New
Mexico](/wiki/New_Mexico "New Mexico"), July 1945

The portable machine gun spread, a notable example being the German
[MG34](/wiki/MG34 "MG34"), and various [submachine guns](/wiki/Submachine_gun
"Submachine gun") which were suited to [close combat](/wiki/Close_combat
"Close combat") in urban and jungle settings.[398] The [assault
rifle](/wiki/Assault_rifle "Assault rifle"), a late war development
incorporating many features of the rifle and submachine gun, became the
standard postwar infantry weapon for most armed forces.[399][400]

Most major belligerents attempted to solve the problems of complexity and
security involved in using large [codebooks](/wiki/Codebook "Codebook") for
[cryptography](/wiki/Cryptography "Cryptography") by designing
[ciphering](/wiki/Cipher "Cipher") machines, the most well known being the
German [Enigma machine](/wiki/Enigma_machine "Enigma machine").[401]
Development of [SIGINT](/wiki/SIGINT "SIGINT") (_sig_ nals _int_ elligence)
and [cryptanalysis](/wiki/Cryptanalysis "Cryptanalysis") enabled the
countering process of decryption. Notable examples were the Allied decryption
of [Japanese naval codes](/wiki/Japanese_naval_codes "Japanese naval
codes")[402] and British [Ultra](/wiki/Ultra "Ultra"), a [pioneering
method](/wiki/Bombe#The_British_Bombe "Bombe") for decoding Enigma benefiting
from information given to Britain by the [Polish Cipher
Bureau](/wiki/Polish_Cipher_Bureau#Gift_to_allies "Polish Cipher Bureau"),
which had been decoding early versions of Enigma before the war.[403] Another
aspect of [military intelligence](/wiki/Military_intelligence "Military
intelligence") was the use of [deception](/wiki/Deception "Deception"), which
the Allies used to great effect, such as in operations
[Mincemeat](/wiki/Operation_Mincemeat "Operation Mincemeat") and
[Bodyguard](/wiki/Operation_Bodyguard "Operation Bodyguard").[402][404] Other
technological and engineering feats achieved during, or as a result of, the
war include the world's first programmable computers
([Z3](/wiki/Z3_\(computer\) "Z3 \(computer\)"),
[Colossus](/wiki/Colossus_computer "Colossus computer"), and
[ENIAC](/wiki/ENIAC "ENIAC")), [guided missiles](/wiki/V-1_flying_bomb "V-1
flying bomb") and [modern rockets](/wiki/V-2_rocket "V-2 rocket"), the
[Manhattan Project](/wiki/Manhattan_Project "Manhattan Project")'s development
of [nuclear weapons](/wiki/Nuclear_weapon "Nuclear weapon"), [operations
research](/wiki/Operations_research "Operations research") and the development
of [artificial harbours](/wiki/Mulberry_harbour "Mulberry harbour") and [oil
pipelines under the English Channel](/wiki/Operation_Pluto "Operation Pluto").

  * _[The World Wars (miniseries)](/wiki/The_World_Wars_\(miniseries\) "The World Wars \(miniseries\)")_ The World Wars is a three-part, six-hour event miniseries by the History Channel that premiered on Monday, 26 May 2014, (Memorial Day) airing for three consecutive nights. An extended version of the series with never before seen footage was subsequently broadcast on H2 and in more than 160 countries on 22 June 2014
  * _[Apocalypse: The Second World War](/wiki/Apocalypse:_The_Second_World_War "Apocalypse: The Second World War")_ (2009), a six-part French documentary by Daniel Costelle and Isabelle Clarke about World War II
  * _[Battlefield](/wiki/Battlefield_\(TV_series\) "Battlefield \(TV series\)")_ , a documentary television series initially issued in 1994–5, that explores many important World War II battles
  * _[BBC History of World War II](/wiki/BBC_History_of_World_War_II "BBC History of World War II")_ , a television series, initially issued from 1989 to 2005.
  * _[The World at War](/wiki/The_World_at_War "The World at War")_ (1974), a 26-part [Thames Television](/wiki/Thames_Television "Thames Television") series that covers most aspects of World War II from many points of view. It includes interviews with many key figures including [Karl Dönitz](/wiki/Karl_D%C3%B6nitz "Karl Dönitz"), [Albert Speer](/wiki/Albert_Speer "Albert Speer"), and [Anthony Eden](/wiki/Anthony_Eden "Anthony Eden").

Additionally, it mentions peace treaties signed in 1951 and 1990.
